reviewText:
Early Access Review

On trying this game, I definitely felt at home playing it, and not because I've played Endless Space prior.  This game takes the 4X system of control in slightly different ways, some of them well done, others, well, it's still Alpha, so they could be cleaned up later.

Combat is definitely a change, as you don't micromanage armies, and as others have pointed out, the combat occurs on the world map you've been running you're army around on.  No 'seperate' field of conflict in this game.  They've definitely nailed the 'Feel like a general managing a conflict as opposed to a lieutenant managing a squad' sense to the combat.  You get teh choice of where to start your armies, and who they focus on, but after you click that launch button, the whole thing is no longer in your hands or control.  And, as you've not been pulled to a seperate screen, if the battle seems the kind to be a while, you can manage you're empire by simply scrolling the map.

Empire building is different, as you aren't looking to just cluster yourself as much as possible to ensure a firm holding, as you've now got Regions to focus on, and each region you settle gives you all but the field goodies without need of actually having a city touching them.  This means less cities to hold larger swathes of land.  And the inclusion of the Watchtower structure gained in Age II helps to further this mechanic.  And since friendly minor factions in the regions provide bonuses to your cities in teh regions, you get even more for less.  And with science being non-linear beyond needing Age X for Tech Y, you can develop in teh ways you feel will most benefit your empire's growth.

The troop 'improvement' system is very much Endless Space feeling, though currently the unit types and selection feels very basic from what will be available in the final game.  The weapon and armor selections also feel sparse to start with.  With only a small number of factions as well, it gets quick to identify what units are what, and which faction they belong to.  Though, currently there appears to be some issues with some unit models not being in the game in a working state for manual battle control, as I had a couple of game halting error logs pop up that required reloading the turn from an autosave to get around, so don't expect to see the troops in combat in all their glory just yet.

The quest system feels clunky at this time, but definitely looks to be on the right road.  It feels head and shoulders above Elemental: Fallen Enchantress's system right now, what with the quests actually feeling like they're part of the world as opposed to just thrown in to extend play-time.  the fact that each faction has a 'Main Quest' chain that's tailored to their culture and mythos (what there is available of it right now) definitely helps with the idea of this being a deeper world.

On the whole, this IS in alpha, so expect a lot of changes to come, but so far, they've done a fairly strong job of building a mythos of the world that helps tie it to Endless Space, and Dungeons of the Endless, and I can't wait to see more of the story brought forward, further revealing how the three games are tied together.  I'm also hoping some of hte mechanics that feel very empty get filled soon, especially has there are a large number of commands and options, from technologies to hero skills, that have the whole 'NOT YET IMPLIMENTED' icon strung upon them making me hope that what's available now is just the tip of the iceburg we've found.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm a fan of Civilization V, but I enjoy fantasy games more than others. Endless Legend might only be in the alpha stage of development, but it's already incredibly fun to play. I recommend this game to anyone who loves fantasy or strategy games. There are cons to this game, as expected, and most of them come from the fact that it's an alpha game. As of this moment, as I'm writing this review, there is no tutorial to the game. Many features such as mulitplayer and the abillity to automate some of your unit's development are not yet implemented. I only just realized on turn 150 or so of my first match/game that you need to manually increase your city's population, thus enabling you to create settlers to expand. Becauset there wasn't a tutorial, it took me 1.5+ hours to figure out how to properly expand your empire. However, believe me when I say that this game is truck-loads of fun. Despite the fact that I couldn't figure out how to play correctly, I'm still immensely enjoying this game. It looks awesome, it feels incredible, but the updates can't get here soon enough. Go buy it. Now. Please. Seriously, you'll thank me later.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWow this game is stunning even in early access.  Combines alot of great elements from Civilization and Warlock and even the Total War games.  The world and ui design are also very intuitive yet full of options.  It's got quests, heros, and i really like the way the battle system works.  Really unique usuage of TB in that you can autoplay with your army or setup your units.  This game really makes great use of ranged units in that way. Hell you can even customize units and create new ones, which often sounds cool, but can get very obtuse in practice.  Music also has been great so far.  Definately don't regret dropping ~$25 to play this now, and more as it progresses.

reviewText:
**Edit 10/2/2014: A bit of information on the tech tree and my feelings on it added.**

Having played an ungodly amount of Endless Space, I of course was looking forward to Endless Legend. And overall, I'd have to say my experience has been a positive one-- but not without numerous potholes.

First, the positives: The graphics are gorgeous. Just totally amazing for a 4X game. Units move fluidly, resources sparkle invitingly, and the transition from summer to winter and back again is just lovely to watch. Then there's the level of customization you can get into with your armies.

It's basically the massive level of outfitting you could do with your ships in Endless Space... but with people! Mix-n-match older tech with new, or just put everyone in the shiniest stuff you can find, and upgrading is nice and easy (if ludicrously expensive sometimes). And the game is definitely engaging; my first playthrough was of the okay

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEndless Legend is a killer new take on 4x strategy games with a fun fantasy setting. Fans of Age of Wonders or Civ will find similarities with this game. Though it does a lot of things similar, there's plenty of questing, exploration, and an in-depth RPG leveling/item system for your characters that make this game just as addicting, even in its alpha state. The game is very polished all things considered, and has enough content that this could be released in its current state and I'd still buy it. I have yet to try multiplayer so I can't speak to its berevity - I will update this review once I have.

reviewText:
The closest thing I've found to solving my Civilization and Age of Wonders cravings at the same time. Absolutely beautiful game, great empire building, and entertaining gameplay.

Pros:
+ The game looks incredible
+ Very fun empire building (none of the empire building aspects are terribly deep, but overall theres a lot of things which lends it depth).
+ Interesting array of units.
+ Resources and diplomacy are easy to understand.
+ Map is somewhat self ordering (its actually a challenge to find and place cities in optimal ways).
+ Quest system is interesting, and for the most part entertaining.
+ Game is very smooth and streamlined if you desire it to be.
+ Improvement system for units is interesting.

Cons:
+ Not a lot of unit diversity. You can recruit units from minor tribes, but in reality its somewhat of a letdown that each empires armies boils down to 3 different units. The game would really benefit from a larger roster of empire specific units (at least one for each type of role) or more units opening up when you recruit a minor faction (the haunts give both flying ghosts and infantry ghouls for example).
+ Combat is a mixed bag. It looks pretty, can be fun at times, and is relatively simple - but by and large is something I mostly skip over.
+ Hero trees are flat out boring.

Neutral:
+ Game sometimes feels like it plays itself at times. Its not a con, because you can always find ways to occupy yourself, but the feeling is still there.

Overall great game. Mostly a empire simulator to be honest.

reviewText:
This game is... really odd.

That's pretty much all I can say about it with complete confidence. Well, other than the fact that I think it is fantastic.

Now, hear me out. This game is a 4x Strategy game with a hex based movement system and all that jazz. That comes with it's own sense of comparison cliches and mechanical trappings, but if you really do enjoy games like Civilization, and AoW and all of those, you will find somethere for you here within the bounds of Endless Legend.

What draws my attention about it the most, is that it really does it's best to make every single game you play feel dramtically different. Each individual aspect can make or break your game, and will have you changing playstyles on the fly. To the random terrain sometimes not giving you the dust you need as a Broken Lord, or the first minor faction you get being absolutely useless, you have a whole host of things that will mess with your style, and keep you on your toes.

That being said, the main issue I have is just how non-confrontational the A.I. is. You kind of feel like you are in the game alone, and it's dreary.

But other than that, Im enjoying myself immensly. I WILL edit the review once I have a chance to experience Multiplayer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Endless Legend is in amazing shape for an Early Access Alpha! I have always been very impressed with Amplitude with the quality of their titles and their constant communication with the player community which actually has a say in how their games develop.

The graphics at this stage are wonderful with awesome tilt-shift effects (selective depth of field blurring) that make the game seem like a tabletop miniatures session when you zoom in (check some of my screenshots)! There is so many little neat details to look at and explore - so many great little finishing touches (like how the playing field becomes a hand drawn hex map as you zoom out) that you just wouldn't expect at this stage of development. Even more amazing is that Amplitude has indicated that they will be making improvements to the graphics as development continues - awesomesauce!

Audio at this stage is above average - not as great as the graphics but totally acceptable at this stage.  Think string quartet kind of stuff - it can get a little sleepy after a long play session but thats just a nitpick. They plan to totally rerecord the audio at a later stage.

Gameplay is a lot like Civilizations V in a fantasy setting. Currently, this is the area that is lacking the most features - auto-development of cities, more in-depth diplomacy, a tutorial, roads and trading, half of the factions (currently 4), etc... it's a long list of features they intend to put in but have not yet at the Alpha stage. Understandable. Anyone familiar with Amplitude knows they are a great studio and will certainly include these missing features as development continues - they just want to do each feature right and give them the dev time they deserve. That said, there is a TON of content already in the Alpha - outdoing many a beta or even finished product I've played. Setting up and equipping armies and adding heros and outfitting them as well are all present and quite intuitive. Combat is fun, even if you let the game auto-resolve. It's still very satisfying. City development, while not fully fleshed out, is quite deep. Random and faction-related quests are present. It PLAYS very much like a game much further down the development road. Kudos!

EL is very intuitive to play, even for players who aren't huge 4x junkies (like myself). Don't be intimidated and not buy this game because of the tag 4x - it's accessible and fun to play with a surprising amount of information that is all easy to get at and digest.

Bugs - sure. There ARE bugs. It's an Alpha. I have encountered FAR less bugs so far in EL than I have in some finished titles. Some are a little annoying (I had one crash the game - once in several play sessions) and some are just minor little things (like variables showin in text instead of unit names).

Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone even remotely interested in playing 4x type games or anyone looking for a great, fun to play, awesome looking strategy title. Once you get it, you can head over to Amplitudes website and start voting on future development features and take an active role in EL's development.

reviewText:
I should say a few things from the beggining. The first thing being, I am not a huge fan of 4X games. Games like Sid Meiers do not appeal to me too much. However, I am a fan of the combat system this game has, so I purchased this for what ever reason. I was not disappointed in the slightest. The movement system is very well-crafted and enjoyable. The addition of tribes and smaller races are very appreciated.

One thing that is very interesting about this game is the major factions to choose from. The ability to choose from several unique, aesthetically-pleasing factions is great. Forming armys with several different units is a good ability. Also, there is a type of character called a Hero in this game. Heroes are a more powerful unit that lead an army. They are a cool addition to these types of games.

Overall, this was a very pleasureable game to play, and I could recommend it to everybody. The basics are easy to learn but hard to master. This is a great game.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic.

Think Civilization 5, but with a truly workable narrative based on your faction, and perhaps a bit deeper in strategy.

The city management/construction system will be immediately familiar but turns out to be deceptively deep and enjoyable. The tech tree allows a ton of freedom on what paths you decide to go down. You equip your units with what items you choose, which harkens back to the days of Alpha Centauri. You have options for units, but it's not so many that it bogs you down--it strikes a great balance.

The combat system is merely alright. It is by no means is bad, but compared to the other facets of the game that are wonderfully polished and/or pleasantly original, the combat, which would seem perfectly in place in a game that was merely good or great, seems to lag behind the otherwise stellar showing of the other aspects. Again, combat is not bad, to be clear, just a bit different and slightly clunky.

I'll mention the narrative once again and also the flavor texts because I like that kind of thing if done lightly. You never get blasted by walls of text, and you can ignore any and all of it if you wish, but taking a few seconds to read the extra sentences of fluff, I've found, really ties the world together. In my first couple of games I actually almost felt as if I was playing a scripted campaign, not a compeltely random map. The music even has me humming along occaisonally, and further adds to the atmosphere and respectable production quality.

I bought the game on sale, then a couple of days later bought most of the DLCs just because I felt like I owed them more money. The base game is worth full price, and I'm a bit ashamed, as a fan of the 4X genre, that I hadn't gotten this when it was brand new.

I don't know what else is left to say other than that at 20+ hours in, I am sure I'll be spending quadruple that in the next few months in Endless Legend. I am looking forward to starting up the next game as a new faction to see how the game plays through with them, as the two of them I've tried thus far are distinctly unique in their playstyle. Playing a multiplayer map with some friends is bound to be a good time as well.

Truly solid experience.

reviewText:
I love this game. It's probably the most well made and rounded 4X game I've played, and even the DLC is completely worth it, each adding great content fairly cheap, compared to many other games I can think that do neither.

I want to point on what I've had in my mind on most of my games, which is the combat AI. It's really brilliant. The units don't just go to the target the shortest way to attack; they will find the best way for them to get a bonus, e.g. if they have to circle around a unit so they can get high ground, then they will. The only complaint I have on that matter is that it would be nice if the support Heroes would give their bonuses and heals to the unit that would need it most, instead of themselves in case they have no action against an opponent (in the case of holding ground).

All being said, I'd definitely recommend this for all fans of 4X games. It's the best choice atm!

reviewText: This game has been really great.  I've loved Civ games in the past (I've put in over 1000 hrs in Civ V), and this game takes what I love about Civ and improves upon the weaker aspects.  The biggest improvement, by far, is the combat.  Combat in Civ has historically just been [this number] vs. [this number].  Civ V did a lot to increase tactical play by removing unit stacking, but it still doesn't hold a candle to Endless Legend.  The city combat system is also leagues ahead of Civ.  I encourage trying this game.  If you like Civ V, this seems like a no-brainer pick-up.

reviewText:
First let me say that I don't think this is a bad game. Its very polished, looks great, the menus are intuitive, and its easy to get an understanding of what your empire is doing in a quick look.

However, this game bored the ever living ♥♥♥♥ out of me.

My biggest problem was the combat. I read reviews and from what I understood, combat was going to be like Age of Wonders 3. And while they share similarities, Endless Legend dumbed it down big time. In this game, you don't individually move your units and attack. Instead, you give a very, VERY general set of instructions. You tell a unit to attack an enemy, no matter if the unit can reach the enemy or not, and thats it. Your unit does its best to get within range and attacks if able. Automatically. There is no tactics, no skill. Its purely who has the most units, who has the smartest units, and who has the best equiped units.

No special powers, no tactical positioning to flank an enemy cause there is no bonus for such things. You can't select one unit, move it out of the way so another unit can move to its spot and attack. You can't even really tell your unit where to go in most cases. While it is true that you can tell your unit to move to a specific place next to an enemy and attack, if that enemy moves before that unit, the unit isn't going to do anything except move because now the enemy isn't where you told your unit to move.

Combat in this game has been dumbed down to Everyone attack this one guy! And if he dies
date: then attack whatever guy you feel like! But be sure to trip over yourselves trying to get within fighting range!" You make sure the red lines are all pointing towards one guy
hoursPlayed:
and watch your units try their little hearts out to attack whatever the red line pointed at.

My next issue is equiping and upgrading your units (I.E. the RPG aspect of this game)

First
voteText: I have an issue with having only one infantry
helpfulPercent: archer/support
votesHelpful: and calvery unit per race. In order to get more units
votesTotal: you have to convince a minor faction (Either by destroying their village in your region then rebuilding it
votesFunny: bribing them

column16:
was pretty lame to me. I like to have multiple units with different abilities so being restricted to less than a hands count sucked.

I was fully expecting to find magical gear like powered up swords or armor and having to choose which units or heroes to give it to. Instead Endless Legend makes you choose between having your one racial infantry unit hold a sword or spear (Doing extra damage to infantry or calvary respectively) and just getting the next "Tier" of armor your technology level allows.

I will admit
column17: I liked being able to upgrade or "Retrofit" as the game calls it my units after adding my newly researched better armor to them immediately. But again
column18:
the upgrade itself is nothing more than equiping the next level of equipment rather than making any real choice as to how to upgrade them.

The heroes was something I liked however. Your heroes have a skill tree with 3 different trees with abilities that can affect them if they are the general of an army or the mayor of a town. Or both in some cases. It did make you have to choose if you wanted a powerful unit or to give a city huge bonuses.

The city building was interesting. Its a mix between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic 6 I believe. Maybe 5. I don't remember. But you build a city anywhere you want in a region

So enemy players can't build a city directly next to your land and take it via influence like in Civilization.\n\nI'm not a real fan of the thumbs up or down method steam uses to rate games because this game itself isn't bad. It was just incredibly boring to me which is why I cannot recommend it."

reviewText: Having played Civ 5 Brave New World i was looking for a breath of fresh air when i purchased this game. At first it seemed a very interesting game but i immediately got bored. Doesnt matter what civ you play it feels you are playing the same thing over and over. The game encourages one type of victory, supremacy.  The more cities you build the more powerful you become, there are almost no negative consequences because of the luxury resources you can exploit. You will have a ton of gold, production, food... and the more you take from the other civs the better. Just conquer everything you see and you will win, its that easy. Maybe with dlcs the game will offer new mechanics but for now it feels you are playing the same game over and over.

reviewText:
One of, if not, THE BEST 4X games ever created. So addictive.

Pros:
-Wonderfully diverse factions each with their own unique style of gameplay.
-Amazing UI and detailed maps
-Top notch music
-Easy to learn but with plenty of nuances to master
-Map generator has never dissapointed me
-Combat system is much more in-depth compared to Civ. You can beat the odds by careful planning and using your head in most situations

Cons:
-AI could use some work, normal difficulty feels very easy
-Combat can drag out turns in the later game when you have multiple armies on different battlefronts (luckily theres an auto comabt option for those times when you are confident)
-End-game could use a little more variety. All of your units are researched by mid game.


In the end, all the good parts of this game definitely outshine the bad parts. I'm sure we'll see more content released in the future to further cement this games place in the 4X history books.

10/10

reviewText:
This game is much more interesting than Civilizations Beyond earth and also deserves a lot more attention.

I managed to think of 14 positives, 1 neutral and 6 negatives.

The Positive:
+ Eight different races that are really completely different and also feel different. They also have different styles to obtain victory
+ The possibility to make custom races based on pre-existing ones.
+ Every race has their own, interesting storyline.
+ More victory types than in Civilizations V
+ Beautiful graphics style
+ Amazing music with a unique sound to it
+ The pace of the game is quicker than in Civilization. You do not have to wait for ages (literally) for just a monument to be built.
+ Immersive fantasy-world
+ Unit customization
+ The game has in-game quests that grant you rewards upon completing them. Also, each faction itself has its own main quest and they are really rewarding since the benefits they give you can be quite large.
+ The combat system is interesting and actually challenging and although it may feel you have little influence at first, there is really a lot you can do to influence it. It is more like telling your units what to do instead of controlling them perfectly.
+ Made by a developer that continues to add new content. For free. Yes. Here, you do not have to buy a ton of silly downloadable content or expansions to make the game more fun. *Winks to Firaxis*
+ Good city building style and management
+ Conquered cities do not lose 75% of the existing buildings like in Civilizations, the same with population. Because of this a conquered city still has value. Also the cities that are founded later in the game are not necessarily behind in the development, because you can buy buildings from the early game for a relatively low price and so the new city can quickly go to the same level of  your older cities.

-+ Science. It is interesting and also non-linear. But it feels a little weird for me. Also, most researches are often focused on just one type of advantage. So, things that purely give you more food, or more Dust (= money), or purely militairy things.


Some negative:
- May be overwhelming in the beginning. Because it can be a little complicated and the game itself provides few explanations.
- The game can get a little laggy near the end of the game. Especially when the winter comes.
- If you compare waging wars in this game to waging wars in Civilization V, then I must say that in Civilization V it was better. Because an army was not a single entity like in this game. There was also nothing more satisfying than rolling several catapults supported by a ton of swordsmen and archers up to an enemy's city and than bombarding the hell out of it. It was rather satisfying. Although sieges in Endless Legend are also good (and I like the idea with units being granted extra health points for defending in a siege) it is simply less exhilerating.
- In continuation of the above. War music. Declaring war on someone and then getting to hear adrenaline-filled songs may be one of the reasons why I always ended up being called the ''warmongering menace'' in Civ V, unfortunately these war/peace themes are not as present as in Endless Legend or do not exist.
- Small variety of units
- No naval combat. The seas are not used for anything more than transporting troops.

I cannot think of more negatives.

In short, I would say that this game is rather innovative and beats Civ Beyond earth any day in the history of mankind, or the future for that matter.

Too long; did not read: simply buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are a lot of people on the fence of buying 'Early Access' games.
They fear it could be a wasted investment, money thrown down in the toliet because the Company went bust, or the game lost interest.
This is not a game you should fear.
Endless Legends while in it's pre-alpha stage still has the ability to be fun, interesting, and challenging.

Pros:
Beautiful Graphics,
Fantastic Combat System (Even in Alpha, remember, still more to come!)
Minor Factions. Note: These can either be your best friends, or your worst enemies.
Diplomacy.

Cons:
Research System - This is really my main concern. The research system is mostly a 'point and wait', For example, I can select any Era I research, and I can select others and they get tasked. Meaning, just click away, and wait for research to be done. This MAY just be A early access thing. So, again. Hold your horses and wait.

Like it says here, on Steam, and you even have to ACKNOWLEDGE when you first play the game:
IT'S A EARLY ACCESS GAME.
You're paying for it, so you can play now, and help the Developers make the game.
Yes, this means bugs. Yes, this means crashing, Yes, this means you can't play with your friends just yet.
But this game is worth the hassle.
Got all my Towns burned, my Hero was slain, the mighty Broken Lord's empire fell silent with a swift blow.
11/10. Would play again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent product for an Early Access.  Despite a few missing features it plays like a finished product.  Players will have to get used to the concept of not having as direct control over their troops in combat, but this actually helps the game flow as it means you aren't so afraid to use Autocombat since the results will be close to what you could have managed manually, which keeps the game moving fast.
Research moves at an excellent pace and the story quests behind each faction remain interesting.  Games play fairly fast but replayability is fine.

All in all, an excellent purchase that I'm glad to have done, continuing the fine examples the Studio has already released.

reviewText:
This one's a bit of a tough recommendation. If youo're looking for a 4x game with a really intriguing story and a neat take on the 4x formula, this is a great game. Also, be prepared to do a lot of micro managing. If you're into that (as I am) you'll have a lot more fun with it. The story behind each of the 8 playable factions is deep enough to get invested in, but open enough for the player to make their own story out of it.

However, there are some very frustrating things with the quest system. Quests are a very important part of the game, but they are by far the weakest part. There are many quests whose completion requirements are overly specific in what is required, and yet strangely general in how they are told. Many times I thought I completed a quest and hadn't because of some minor detail which wasn't fully recounted. For example, one quest required me to grow a city to the size of 8. The city was already at a size of 14, but the quest didn't complete. I had to starve the city down to 7 population, and then re-grow it to get the completion on the quest. Possibly that was intentional, but it was extremely frustrating. Twice, the game actually bugged in such a way that completing a quest was impossible.

There have also been more than a few crashes, but the game autosaves every turn so it's not that much of a problem, and with luck that will get fixed in a later patch.

Overall, mostly great 4x game that could use a few patches. If the quests are fixed and the crash bugs are removed, this game is very solid.

reviewText:
I've played a lot of strategy games over the years and this is one of the better ones. A lot of 4x games (not including space 4x) tend to be heavily modeled after the Civilization series, not Endless Legend though. This game is very much its own game.

Pros:
Each Faction plays very differently from each other. Necrophages can't have peace or alliances, Broken Lords don't need food. Drakken can force peace upon another player, Roving Clans can't declare war etc. Each faction truly is a vastly different playstyle.

The game is beautiful. A minor thing that just makes it more enjoyable.

The battle system is interesting. More in depth than Civ's smack two units against each other, but not as in depth as Age of Wonders 3 where you control each unit on the battle field.

The world is very diverse and there are quests, ruins, minor factions etc. that make exploring both profitable and enjoyable.

Unit Customization. You can alter your units with different armor, weapons and trinkets to suit your needs. You take a basic unit from your faction (or assimilated minor factions) and equip them with different equipment to make them stronger or more specialized. For instance you could have a lance weilding Stalwart that does a lot of damage, or one that can take as much damage as you throw at it.

Heroes: Strong units that lead armies or govern cities. Very useful and very cool.

Mixed:
The region system is somewhat strange. When you settle a region with a city, you own that whole region. However, only the tiles directly around your city are worked. You also can only found a single city per region. This means that many areas that would make excellent cities are wasted. On the other hand all the strategic and luxury resources in the region can be harvested by the single city. You also don't get AI settling right next to your city to steal a resource like in Civ.

Cons:
Limited number of Units. Each faction only has 4 base units. You can assimilate different minor factions for their units but there is a limited number of slots to do this. Compared to other games there aren't many units around. However each faction has three unique units (the settler is common to almost all the factions).

AI can travel into your territory automatically and can attack your units outside of your territory without declaring war. You have to declare peace for them not to be able to attack your units and declare closed borders to keep them out of your territory. Both of which cost influence.

Declaring war costs influence. Severely annoying and pointless. The other diplomatic stuff makes sense. This does not. You don't need to influece someone to declare war, you just attack them.

reviewText:
Played the game for a few hours yesterday, and while I'll readily admit, 7.8 hours is not really enough to get a true feel for the game, I have seen enough to know that the developers have put a lot of thought into this game.  The atmosphere seems right, difficulty may be set a tad high for people new to the 4X genre of games (either that or I'm just terrible at this game haha).

There are a few bugs that need fixing, they're mainly game crashes.  Suffered a fair number of them yesterday while playing Multiplayer with my friend, either desyncing or just plainly dropping us both out the game and leaving us with a window saying the other person closed the game....  If you're considering buying this game, don't let these little blips put you off, the game is well worth a purchase if you're looking for a 4X game you can get your teeth into.

Price for this game is just right IMO

reviewText:
I have endless space and although I liked it I didn't really give enough time to fully enjoy it. Lots of people say this is endless space in a fantasy setting. I disagree. Although some of the mechanics are similar this game is different. Its also different and a lot more fun than many other fantasy based 4X titles.

So far I am into my first game and practically did not stop for 14 hours. Yes this game does an excellent job of keeping you in it. The game has a brief tutorial which does a great job of familiarising you with the basics. At first the game does appear a bit daunting with so many options and things to remember. After a couple of hours I became comfortable and then everything just seem to get better as my Empire slowly came to life. Breaking my 4x tradition I decided to start with a faction thats focus is on economy. I have to say  its really been good. It makes a change to buy your way to success instead of relying on churning out a constant army. With this faction I buy my army and its ready in an instant. The game consists of several varied and interesting major factions and then you have numerous minor factions.  Whichever major faction you choose they will have their own unique background story and quests.

Units vary but are basically broken down into heroes, support, infantry, cavalry, ranged and flying. You can even make your own units. To conquer regions you need cities and growing your city is a long process. In fact as your research grows you will enter several different ages unlocking even more ablities for the city. As well as battles this game is very much about resource management. I love the way every single hex in the game produces some kind of resource in different quantities. This makes it especially important when deciding where to place your city.

This game is pretty much all about time and planning. I really like it that at the beginning of the game you will be in whats known as a 'cold war' with all the other factions. At this stage there can be no peace treaties and you are quite exposed if you end up next door to an aggressive neighbour. Diplomacy in endless legends takes a long time to bear fruit. One thing I do like about the AI on easier settings is that it doesn't tend to attack you the moment it stumbles across you. I've played too many 4X's in the past where you literally get jumped on by the AI before you have started. The great thing about endless is that you start off with a limited number of diplomatic options. The others only come later if you research them. All the other AI factions in the game behave in a specific way. Some are expansionists while others are pacifists. This becomes apparent over time when you see how the factions behave towards each other and the size of their territory.

On to the map. Its one of the best and most intuitive I've seen in a 4x. Randomly generated hex landscapes with varied environments from cold wastes to desert. Each will effect how units interact with it. Scattered across the landscape are numerous weird anomalies, exploitable resources, explorable ruins and minor factions. At any point you can smoothly zoom right in and out of the map to get an overview of the empires. The map is big and takes a long time to fully explore. Minor factions play a role in that you need to pacify them early or they will become a threat with their wandering armies. You can even assimilate a limited number of pacified factions which will give you access to one of their units.

Battles are fought on a zoomed in version of the region it takes place on. Then its a simple turned based hex battle which goes through a number of phases before the outcome is decided. The environment your units are in at the time will have an effect. Some may think the battles are too simplified with limited options and no spell books like with HoMM games. To be honest I think it works just fine for endless. After a battle if you win your units will earn experience points and gradually level up. This makes keeping veteran armies alive essential for the later game.

The music score is superb and blends into the game perfectly.

There is a lot more to this game than what I have touched on in this review. Be sure that once its got your attention you will be sinking endless hours into it.

10/10

reviewText:
Quite honestly I was on the fence on whether or not to make the purchase on this game.  The screenshots and overall favorable reviews is what sold it to me.  I'm a huge fan of the 4x strategy games and with that being said, I was NOT disappionted in the slightest way with Endless Legend.

Some of the pros with this game include the graphics.  Great graphics, especially when compared to games like Civ and Fallen Enchantress.  The units and factions are also completely fresh.   There are your typical archers and melee units which are both essential to any 4x game but take my word for it, a lot of units are at least slightly different and most are really cool (Especially on your first few play throughs when you first encounter them).  Another pro for me is the added involvement regarding the city building aspect of the game.  Each time your city gains population you gain a Worker" that you can place in specific parts of the building/production within your cities.  If you need buildings or units produced more quickly put more of your "Workers" in the production.  Technologies not getting researched fast enough place them into the science slot etc.

With this being said
date: the game isn't without it's downfalls (In my opinion).  I prefer to have more control over my units during combat.  I would rather control each unit for each move.  This isn't the case in Endless Legend.  When your units are involved in a a battle you basically follow the certain steps.  First off
recommended: the battle map is basically a zoomed in portion of the current location of the map that unit is currently on (This for me is actually a plus and definitely a welcomed change).  However
hoursPlayed: the battle sequence leaves a bit to be desired.  To start you basically have to place your units.  Then you select what you want them to do whether it be to attack a specific unit or if you have a healing unit etc. you decide who you want them heal etc.  The battle then ensues until the next turn where you have the option to change your strategies and the battle sequence proceeds as previously mentioned.  Some may prefer this method as it is simplified but I prefer battle sequences like Age of Wonders 3.\n\nThe modifications also leave a little to be desired for me as well.  Personally I love that fact in Fallen Enchantress where you can outfit your heroes with anything and it shows on the character
voteText: not only on the character screen but when you see them in the world too.  With Endless Legends this portion is true in regards to the weapon and Shield only.  Any new armor etc can be equipped but you will not see them.\n\nOverall I do recommend the game and it has kept me busy for about 16hrs since purchase and I'll be busy for many more hours because of the differences it offers to the genre.  It is fun and when I want a slight change in units/factions/city buidling I'll be starting this one up!"

Great game with great mechanics. I was a bit unhappy at first when I learned each race only had three race-specific units, but the customization of units and minor faction units more than makes up for the lack of diverse race-specific modeling.

The game does a great job of keeping development and technology moving forward, while maintaining a medieval, fantasy world.

reviewText: I've sunk many hours into this game ever since I had to take a few days off after getting sick. I've played through several full games as the different factions and found that each of them is very unique. I'd say that this is the biggest thing that the game has over Civilization V. If you're at all interested I recommend you read up on each of these because it would take too long to explain here. The other two big differences are a quest and combat systems. Unlike Civ5's city state quests, they don't involve racing other factions or killing another city state(there are none). They're a bit more interesting and present some semblance of a story for each of the factions. Of course, there's not much depth to be expected of quests in a 4X game, but they do make the game a bit more interesting. The combat system, on the other hand, isn't very good and is kind of tedious, especially because of the slow animations. So I wouldn't recommend picking this game up just becasuse you like turn-based combat. But still, it's there and does add SOME depth to combat which would otherwise just be RNG-based.\n\nI recommend this game, but I'm also not sure if it feels done yet. I've been playing on the 'Hard' difficulty and I've found that diplomacy and other AI behaviors are a bit irrational. I hope this is something that will be addressed in a future patch. I expect it to be.

reviewText:
Endless Legend is very much in the vein of civilisation but with a fantasy setting.
It has more depth than many games of its ilk with a wide range of troops, minor factions and resources.
Unlike many modern games the factions are very different with unique play mechanics that making using a different faction a very different experience.
Recommended for fans of fantasy strategy games.



Added after 23 hours play:

Having played this for longer there are game crashing bugs and occasional errors. Autosaves happen every turn to rescue you from this. If you get errors without a crash then it is best to exit the game as re-opening the game can fix the errors. Hopefully these issues will be fixed in a future patch but be warned if you see an error the game may crash in a future turn but your save is probably fine if you restart.

Some of the features I like from this game:

Seasons mean winter suddenly drops your food and other production, poorly designed empires can find them selves starved. Troops move slowly in winter and it gives a sensible pause in war efforts. Once you have troops with winter resistence via high level skills you can gain advantages in the winter.

Diplomacy has a default state of cold war, one step from peace or war. Peace and Alliances must be researched before being offered and military players can not only ignore diplomacy but also ignore chunks of the research options.

Troops can be edited to give them the latest equipment, then troops built on those original builds can be retrofitted to the current build.

Heroes stationed in cities earn experience as quickly or faster than combat Heroes. The earn experience for everything built at the city so defensive and peaceful empires can still build powerful heroes. Heroes also have a whole chain of skills focused on city boosting.

Each faction has a recommended victory type to aim for.
Cultists for example can only build one city and expand through village conversion instead. Each village gives them resouces, an extra city worker and troops are generated for free in the village. The city can grow a level higher than any other faction and numbers of workers in the end game can be very high due to all the villages converted.
To play each faction to the full you need to embrace there game mechanic and just playing each faction gives a lot of replay.

Difficulty is simpler than other games in the ilk as long as you follow the correct playstyle for your faction and utilise your heroes fully. Anything below normal should be treated as training and normal may be to easy if you play a lot of strategy games.

My first playthroughs with the Wind Walkers took 15+ hours and my second play with Cultists taking less than 8 hours.
If you ignore the story line quests and focus on a quick win on maps other than huge you could do this in a much shorter time.
Playing the remaining factions I expect to spend another 30-60 hours trying out the other 6 main factions.

reviewText:
Endless legends is a game unlike any I have played before. It begins much in the way a game of civilizaiton would, you place a capital and branch out to new cities through the use of settlers, conquests, bribes, and even an intriguing quest system. If you enjoy games like civilization revolution then you will love this unique twist and style that endless legends brings to the genre.

While this game is one of the best games of the genre it does have its draw backs. Throughout my play through I began to notice a few irritating things that I feel are necessary to understand about this game before purchase. My first point would be to say that this game is not one that encourages variety. Every faction has three basic units that are unlocked fairly early on, and then they are allowed to assimilate a few minor factions along the way in order to broaden their unit scope. While this may not seem like a big deal to many people it does put certain factions at a major disadvantage against experienced players. My most recent encounter with this is that the Mezari start the game with ranged units that are able to move and shoot all in the same turn, this allows them to kite early game fights and put almost all other factions into the dirt early game. While this may seem like something that many people see as counterable you have to realize that certain factions such as the drakken and the broken lords have no way of countering a ranged unit as they have no late game ranged units of their own without using a valuable assimilation slot.

While this game does have its flaws, it is almost impossible to pass up. Its unique quest system sets it apart from the other titles in this genre, as you now no longer have to build a final building but instead with each faction you are encouraged to follow a specific path that will also allow you win the game. Knowing these paths for each faction you are offered a very interesting way of now denying your allies victory, without having to declare war. We also see the hero system in this game help to further its path to the top of my list of most played games. This game rewards those who use its heroes correctly, offering multiple skill tree paths and roles for heroes. A fully leveled hero in this game could be the difference maker in a battle, as a support hero might be what is needed to keep one militia group alive against multiple titans.

I strongly recommend this game to any lovers of the civilization series, it sticks to the basic city building aspect of the civ series, all the while giving a unique spin on the battle system and diplomacy system.

reviewText:
Endless Legend took me by surprise. I have been a huge Civilization 5 player, with 263 hours on file at the moment, and my heart had always belonged with that game. I recently found interest in Endless Legend and purchased it and I think its a game that every fan of the 4x genre should play or at least look into.

Pros:
1. Beautiful, intriguing world. Tons of inventive lore infused throughout the game.
2. Emphasis on effective empire management. City-building, economy balancing, and researching the tech-circles are really fun. There is also a great emphasis on resource management, each worker you unlock can be placed in different points of emphasis for more resource gain. If you are play a science victory you may want more workers placed in science production to research quickly. If you are playing a supremacy race you may be more interested in placing your workers in industry so you can build units/city expansions quicker, etc...
3. Combat is done nicely. You can choose to tactically face your opponent in a way that sort of reminds me of Heroes of Might and Magic. It is turn-based and there may be some strategy. If you don't like that you can choose to spectate and watch the computer make your moves for you or you can just auto-resolve and move on. If you auto-resolve or spectate, you can choose for the computer to be aggressive or passive as well. You can also upgrade units with new weapons that you can craft through the research tree, or find in quests.
4. Different factions that actually play quite differently. Some factions just simply cannot do certain things. Such as the necrophage, they can't create peace treaties. They are simply a faction that is meant to kill everything. Playing as the necrophage you may want to push all your workers into industry in order to build your improvements/milita quicker. Playing as the ardent mages you may want to move your workers into science production so that you can rush through the research tree and race to a science victory. There is even a faction that relies solely upon Dust (the games gold currency).
4. Some innovative features that haven't been seen in 4x genre. For example: race-specific quest lines that actually serve as a unique victory condition, seasonal effects (summer/winter), the concept of regions limiting city placement, reinforcements, how heroes are handled (as generals or governors), etc., etc.
5. The seasonal affects may actually impact some factions play. I know that whenever I enter the winter my production slows greatly. I end up losing roughly 60 gold per turn and most of the units can only move 1 space or so.
6. You can assimilate with minor factions and build/upgrade their units once you acquire them. They also have bonuses that they will provide to your city once you control them.
7. The artstyle is very intriguing.
8. It isn't like other 4x titles. In fact it does a very good job at seperating itself from other 4x titles (civ 5, age of wonders, etc..)
9. You can create your own factions with all the different perks and army units that are provided in the base game. So if you don't like the factions that are in the game you can customize your own from the bottom up.

Cons:
1. A.I. is kind of bad with certain factions. With the Drakken they are really strong but with some of the other factions they act kind of stupid. This is the game's greatest downfall. But with the modding community helping this out and patches still being worked on (i think) this will come to an end hopefully.
2. It would be cool if there were more factions. I'm sure there are other factions you can download through mods but it would've been cool to see more than just 9 factions in the base game.
3. To some this is a con: The game is not as easily learned as something like Civ 5. Each turn you have to remember where your units were, you have to remember which direction they were heading, and what they were doing. There is more micromanaging in this game with emphasis on what workers produce which things. There are some things you may even have to wiki as well. There is a lot of things you will just learn the more you play considering the game doesn't really hold your hand at all. Even the tutorial is very basic and doesn't quite go over everything you will face in the game itself.

Summary:
When i play this game i instantly compare this game to an RPG. There are very many RPG like elements that are fused with the 4x style and this game does it VERY well. The artstyle is very unique and the way it plays is somewhat similar to what HeroScape was like back in the day. In my opinion it is more smooth that Civ 5 and there is more thought that is required within each turn. There aren't many situtations where you will just sit there and continuously hit the end-turn button. There is always a goal in each turn whether it is working towards the factions quests, trying to parley and assimilate with a minor faction, or expand. Yes, the AI needs improvement, but overall I think this is a great game. I wouldn't even say that the AIs mistakes are as noticeable as some of the other strategy games that exist. Playing on higher difficulties even create a loss more often than not so I think that creates a nice challenge sometimes.

reviewText:
I was surprised, and very impressed, by how good this game is. The game map is the most beautiful I've seen in a strategy game, even more so than Civ V. They've also managed to do a fantasy strategy game right, each faction (all EIGHT of them) is very distinct and unique. The game plays like a mash up of Civ and Elemental Fallen Enchantress, taking all of the best parts from each. The tech tree is broad and you'll make meaningful decisions about which techs to pick up and which to skip. I do wish heroes had a bit more oomph in their leveling. It is also a shame that changing armor load outs on units/heroes doesn't affect their appearance in any way.

The biggest issue with the game is that it's fairly complex, and despite having a good tutorial to introduce you to the UI and basics of the game, some more advanced mechanics are not explained, and the game's wiki is pretty bare bones.

That said, overall the game is great, you should play it if you're a strategy/fantasy fan.

reviewText:
I gotta say I'm actually completely surprised with this game. I half-expected a game that only feels like it's jsut trying to be another Civ game, but what I got was a game that does draw inspiration from Civ 5, but doesn't really feel similar.

First off, alot of the things that really annoyed me about Endless Space are no longer here. Actually none of them are.
1. The AI is actually less stupid and basic and WAY less hard to fight at Easy difficulty.
2. The game's combat system uses none of that stupid freaking card crap from Endless Space which is always better to go without in my opinion, making victory more about strategy and less about chance. Combat has about as much chance as Civ 5 or any 4X game has.
3. The game doesn't feel or seem like it's trying to be Civilization 5, or trying to sell itself as such, instead this game feels like it's actually on it's own ground, although connected to Civ 5, that's not remotely bad however.

The UI from Endless Space is the only reason I still occasionally played it, but now that this game is out and has an even better version of it, which has only very tiny differences to make it all the more better, I've got no reason to play Endless Space anymore.

The game's handling of city's makes things much less complicated in one way while allowing more complication in another way.

Each region can only have a single city, but the game is set up into multiple regions. Each city's limits are capped at the edges of a region, and the city limits are expanded using burroughs.
This makes a sort of promise that you'll be spending less time worrying about city placement in relation to the other cities on the map, but it makes he same promise that you'll be spending more time in macro managing your cities over time.

The game (like Civ) has many resources and special tile benefits that (if worked) bestow huge bonuses to a city, and ofcourse in turn, your empire.

Unlike Civ however, there are no gimmicky things which give you bonuses over others or makes your life more difficulty if not utilized, such as Culture, Tourism or Religion, there also is no ability to move over water tiles however as the regions always end after the first water tile of any palce's coast.

The usual difficulties from endless Space are there, and if anything, this game has a bit of a sense that it's like a prequel to Endless Space, most likely intended due to the title of this game and Endless Space.

In my opinion... This game is fun, it's rather challenging with the Minor races sometimes getting very aggressive at random times, the other civilizations seem to be less warmongering (unless you're the Necrophages, you know... the Krogan disease from Mass Effect, only with undead) in comparison to their previous game, and that is honestly really quite nice.

The way the game handles technology is awesome, and I wish other games did such. The game's technologies are split up into 4 Eras. researching 9 in one era will unlock the next and advance you to it, and so on until the 9th (where I imagine techs to get a science victory would be possible.

The game has none of the dead wonders you could find in Space, thank the gods as in my opinion, they detracted and were often not worth restoring unless you could manage 20 turns of getting something that would boost only approval, or would boost science just a bit.

My first game with 5 others took 4 hours and it's not even over yet, I've yet to get past the 2nd Era, but that is mostly due to the fact i spent 100 turns with 1 city, and that's never something you wanna do honestly.

Overall, the game's very fun, original in it's own ways and has enough bits from Endless Space that it enhances what's already there, as certain aspects of Endless Space were already great, and... well why not use what's already great in another Turn-based game right?

There's some things I haven't said like the factions, or how there's heroes and how they're awesomely powerful, but I highly recommend you to atleast play it for yourself, you will enjoy what you see and experience. If you have doubts, then just ask a friend to play their copy, or do some research with gameplays and other reviews.

My final Verdict for this game, is an 8/10, it's honestly one of the most fun 4X games I've played in a while for the first time.

reviewText:
This game is everything I had hoped Warlock: Master of the Arcane and Elements would be.

The game at it's core is a 4x strategy game. You build towns and armies, develop them and conquer the world or become the world's leader through the several other victory types. However the implementation is better, with clever changes to many of the mechanics:

Combat is handled through tactical battles on the world map. Once hostilites start an area of the map is sectioned off to be used as the battle field, allowing you to know the terrain beforehand. though exploiting that is a little difficult. Rather then precise commands you give broad directions or targets in combat, which makes battles quick and brutal compared to other 4x games with tactical combat.

Towns hold a territory/province stopping town clustering though town placement is very important since the town only gathers resources from ajacent tiles, though extractors can be built on far away strategic or luxury resources. Additionally provinces have minor factions who can be convinced to join you via quests or bribes, or wiped out and built back up. These minor factions provide free workers and can be incorporated into the empire to give faction wide bonuses along with new units.

Units are quite customizable. You can choose from a few different armor and weapon types that vary depending on the type of units. The factions only get a few types of units which can then be customized to fit different roles and more unit types can be gained from the minor factions.

The factions themselves have quite a bit of variety from some factions which don't take food, to others that can't declare war, to another that cannot not be at war and even one that can only build one super town. Factions can also be customized, though the default factions seem to use more points then you get. Additionally the factions have interesting backstories that are fleshed out more on their faction specific quests.

So far the only real complaint I have is that the game is not balanced towards large maps. Expanding is punishing until high level techs are researched making much of a larger map unused. Otherwise this is probably the best 4x game I have played in awhile.

reviewText:
If you are on the fence about buying this game I'm going to say a couple things first. 1. Check to see if your computer meets the requirements. Double check and triple check it even. I neglected to thinking my computer could run it since it can run a lot of more demanding stuff but turns out it can't so the game crashes a lot at random. I can still play the game but it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ to have to watch for crashes and restart the game. 2. You'll get much more enjoyment out of this game if you are already familiar with the Endless Space universe and lore. It's still a fine 4X strategy game but it's not too special if you don't appreciate the Endless Space lore.

That being said here's some pro con action.
Pros: Excellent soundtrack, keeping in tradition with Endless Space the game is has a very comfy atmosphere with it's music
It's damn pretty for a 4X game even on low end settings I'm impressed, I'm not sure there's another game out there that compares to this game on the graphics level in the same genre.
The AI is challenging but fair, it tends to make some really petty decisions though like oh I see your army has visited my lands! you're banned from the market now lol" but each enemy empire has unique personalities a la the civilzation games
As mentioned earlier the lore and universe of Endless Space is important here and if you can appreciate it you'll get more out of the individual faction quests. The quests overall add something unique to the 4X genre and even though all of the sidequests tend to be random the main quests for each faction adds something cool to do when you're not doing other 4X activities.
Also keeping in tradition with Endless Space each of your units are completely customizable

reviewText:
What can I say, this game is all I was looking for in a 4X game:
Amazing theme - Fantasy Sci-Fi
Great graphics & sound
Complex, but not overwhelming
Interesting and innovative mechanics - different to other standard 4X games
Factions actually feel unique and have different fundamental concepts
It's fun

Now I'm just gonna throw this out there right now, I'm not at all a 4X player. I barely play strategy games. I had a strategy itch so I played this and Age of Wonders 3, and I prefer this to be very honest. It's just a more rounded experience. AoW3 seems to be heavily focused on the combat, and a barely on the empire building aspect. Just two very different games.

What can I say, it's good. Watch some videos if you are not convinced. Did I mention that every time you zoom in on the map it looks like a Game of Thrones intro?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a big Civ V fan, I was desperately looking for an alternative after having spent over 600 hours conquering the known world. I'm always skeptical at fantasy clone of civ, because since Master of Magic back in the 90's no developer has ever managed to create a balanced 4x fantasy game. Even the recent Warlock series become way too easy in end game when powerful spells just break the game.

Endless Legend however, althought being set in a fantasy world, avoids the magic trap" (you can't research or cast spells) by offering a profound and refreshing approach to the 4x genre. The game revolves more around resource management
recommended: rather than combat. Think of it of as a Game of Thrones Manager 2014
hoursPlayed: where you keep control over regions by either dominating the minor factions that inhabit them by force or diplomacy. Aslo the graphical environment reminds me a lot of the GoT opening credits style.\n\nRight now the game is far from being finished now
voteText: and the two main reasons I haven't poured more hours into this game are the simplistic AI (no diplomacy

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's not finished. It's far from finished actually, though it already looks polished. In fact, I'm pretty sure it's still in Alpha as of writing this.

However, the game has already seen a lot of growth and looks good enough to play anyways. There are parts of the game that still need balancing, such as military numbers, happiness, and well... a good number of things basically. However, it is very clear that the team behind this game is in it for the long haul, and it is evident they care a lot about their customers, including updates about ongoing progress to future updates to the game.

I don't expect updates every four weeks. I expect updates that have meat behind them and that builds onto the game, especially for an Early Access Game. Even though I haven't played it for hours on end, I can feel it. Even before this game goes into final release, I will be fully addicted to it by Beta.

For those who are looking for fast paced gameplay or a simplified tactical play, this is not your game. For those looking for a magitech take on Civilization with turn based tactical combat, story mode, and even RPG elements including upgrading heroes with weaponry and abilities, this is the game you should keep a very close eye on during development.

reviewText: This is the first 4X game I haven't felt overwhelmed by. The combination of RPG elements and aesthetics (A+ to the graphics and UI, very intuitive for the most part) that makes me want to keep playing. It's challenging and the gameplay has a lot of depth; I've only played three races and each one has a pretty distinctive playstyle. I do wish there was a more in-depth guide available (the manual is okay but really basic) because it did take a while to figure out how to parley and assimilate minor factions, as well as a few other gameplay elements. The combat is fairly simple, but I wish you were able to exercise more control over your units rather than the game moving them around and attacking your target. In a sense, you only semi-control your army and one wrong move (or rather, them charging at the enemy when you're trying to move away...) can cost the battle. Overall, everything feels really polished and gameplay is excellent aside from a few minor issues.

reviewText:
My first impression of this game was stunning.

°°° Is this review too long or are you too la.. eager to buy/play? ;-) Scroll down for a summary. °°°

A good tutorial that covers everything you need to know while being as short as possible, so you can jump right into the real action, something I really appreciate in this kind of games.

Excellent UI, canceling out of menus by right-clicking, all menus are automatically centered on your screen. All infos you need to know are either blent into the HUD or can be toggled. (However, the UI doesn't accept shortcuts, you must navigate it with the mouse)

Overall, Endless Legend plays like a fantasy Civilization with a combat system similar to Heroes of Might and Magic, though, kept as simple as possible (starting combat will form a battlefield directly on the world map and will begin with a tactical phase in where you can place your units strategically on the terrain while showing you the starting area of your enemies. The area both armies can place their units is affected by hero abilities). Combat can be fought manually, automatically or in a semi-automatic fashion. Nice touch: you can choose this in every turn of the combat, giving you the option to change commands for each unit in every turn if you feel that it's necessary.
Very short turns, most of the time shorter than to the comparable Civilization 5.

Heroes can be used as generals for your army or as mayors and can be specialized and equipped accordingly to enhance their abilities for their chosen position.

The most interesting resource in Endless Legend is influence, unlike other strategy games, diplomacy in Endless Legend needs influence for all actions. Declaring war or forming alliances costs influence.
Even if an AI is traitorous and tends to backstabbing, it can only do so if it isn't wasting its influence, making diplomatic predictions possible.
Your overall relation to other factions is cathegorized and can be seen in a 3D (rather 2,5D) UI, hovering over one of those cathegories, displayed as concentric areas will tell you the conditions and costs for actions you can take, and which there are. Entering one of those cathegories through diplomacy or actions will add penalties for violating them.
You swore localty to your allies? Well, you better stick to your words or you will lose influence! Awesome feature and the best solution for an immersive diplomacy I have seen so far.

**One of the best features of this game is the creation of your own units. By conquering neutral factions on the map, you gain their unit-designs, from which you can create your OWN units, e.g. you talk some valkyr-styled, female knights into joining your empire, then take their standard unit and create a unit-template with their model and abilities as basics and now equip them with weapons, armor and accessoires according to your wishes, the accumulated cost for this will further be the cost for reproducing this unit - You can even name this new unit!**

Graphically, this game can easily compete with its competitors. However, on max details, Endless Legend only reaches the average settings of AAA titles. To be more precise, there are no fancy shaders, no max-zoom - high-detail clouds for eye-candy and the basic textures for hex fields are low-res, however, this does not apply to resources on those hex tiles. The visual art style for buildings, ruins and everything else is absolutely fitting and marvellous.
(You can, however, zoom out very far to see whole world where the map changes into an actual map" with borders and region names
date: this has a very nice and immersive feeling to it!)\n\nFog of war covered areas are flat and rise from the ground level

reviewText:
GOOD:
- Pretty. Sparkly.
- Factions play quite differently from each other.
- Frequently updated, with an expansion coming soon.
- Customizable factions, and lots of world generation options.
- Minor factions (think city states) can give you passive bonuses and unique units.
- Lots of win conditions.
- Reinforces my opinion that winter is the worst season.

MIXED:
- The combat is weird. You assemble military units into armies, which can be moved around as a group, so you don't have to give orders to each of your fifteen thousand units. Then you smash your armies into other armies. You have very little control over actual fighting, which can be annoying, but if one army is much stronger than the other, you can just auto-resolve the fight to save time.

BAD:
- UI is too busy, and the text is too small.
- No mini-map or strategic mode.
- Diplomacy needs major changes, as any agreements you make can be broken immediately. (Market ban rage!!)
- Almost nobody is playing multiplayer.
- There's no way to tell a city to produce nothing (or just gold/science like Civ). It will nag you every turn.
- The AI is mega stupid and unfriendly, even on the easiest difficulty.
- The world is split into pre-defined regions, and you can only have one city per region.
- Quests are too strict. I've had to raze several of my own cities in order to re-do stuff the quest demanded.
- Certain sounds don't behave according to volume settings.
- I have a good computer, and yet a duel between me and an AI lags worse than a six person Civ multiplayer game.
- No steam workshop at the moment.
- Very few characters for city/army names.

This sounds like a lot of complaining, but I actually like the game. It just hurts my eyeballs after a while. It's not better than Civ 5, however. If you've never played this sort of game before, seriously get Civ 5 instead. If you've already played Civ and want something new, this is a decent pick up.

reviewText:
I recommend this game if you are already familiar with the basics and techniques needed to play. As this is my first for this type of game i found it very difficult to get used to as the tutorial was less informative..

I started to play with bots and the game told me it was easy even a plant could win.. (Or something along those lines)

I lost as i began to familiarize myself with the game mechanics. I wasnt happy with the results but i figured that i shouldnt give up.

I lost again as i got dominated by the roaming monsters who are completely ****ing with my capitals.. Once again i was let down and couldnt understand why plants were so good at this game.. So i booted another match, accidently misclicking the multiplayer button that i hadnt known existed.

I wondered throughout that match why the enemies were so keen to start a war with me so early into the game,, although at this point i was starting to understand what settlers were for.... And wondered why i was always the smallest province than everyone else...
they took that opportunity to knock me out of the game early..

BUT!
The reason i recommend this game is because even though it was difficult to understand a grab basics to, i still came back to it and had fun in doing so, while never really becomming agitated to rage quitting...

i also intend on playing again and getting better, so i can dominate poor newbies with only one province....

reviewText: A beautifully thought out game. Gorgeous environments, a simple but powerful UI, unique factions, and an amazing soundtrack.\n\nAmplitude have taken all of Endless Space's criticism into account when designing Endless Legend, and it shows. While ES suffered from generic races, every race in EL has unique abilities and aesthetics; Ardent Mages can create temporary pillars to boost production, the Roving Clans cannot declare war but can engage in false-flag operations, etc.

reviewText: Imagine if Civ tried to be a fantasy RPG where you have minor factions (e.g. dwarves, orcs, etc.) instead of barbarians that you can assimilate into your empire and gain their units for production. Then imagine each major faction has a wierd modification that completely changes the way you play the game such as: removing food as a resource and making you buy citizens and repair units with dust (money), forcing you to only have one city that can become a super city, or being able to pick up your cities and walk them over to another tile and plop them down, as well the ability to craft your own faction.\n\nThats about half of the features of this game.

reviewText:
only complaint is the combat system. You don't really get to make any decisions when you go into the tactical battle screen and it seems to serve no other purpose than to provide a stage upon which to watch the units display their individual animations. I would really like to see a patch that allows for more manual control of each battle, otherwise I'll continue to hit auto resolve each time for the sake of saving time.

other than that the game is fun. the quests offer a good distraction from the typical empire building and city management of a 4X game, and reminds me of other titles in the genre like Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Hero's but with more style. The backstory and world-building is compelling as well, and the diplomacy system is one of the best I've seen in this genre.

reviewText:
This caught me by surprise - I rarely feel engaged by 4x games (outside of Civ), but this title really has merit.

Let's get the basics out of the way - it looks great. The artistry is top-notch. The UI is fluid, and importantly doesn't waste your time with animations that freeze your ability to navigate. Everything is responsive and satisfying.

The minor factions are a great addition - something Civ struggled with all the way through 5 (with the city-states). Endless manages to make the minor factions feel just right"
date: and conquering/parlaying/bribing them is a huge part of the game. Plus it's just plain fun to sometimes gain their trust through quests
recommended: and sometimes through conquest. Every option feels equally viable
