column19: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm pretty wary of Early Access these days, but having played and enjoyed Endless Space, I decided to go for it and was not disappointed. Even in the Early Access stage, the polish and promise of this game was unusual. Graphics? Gorgeous. Sound? Beautiful. Gameplay? So much fun. Difficult, but fun. (Maybe it's just the way I play, but I found the Newbie difficulty level to be similar to Civ 5's normal difficulty. It's very easy to fall behind, so get started early and don't waste turns if you can help it!)

It's also got some features that make it stand out from other 4X fare. The light RPG elements (similar to Endless Space, but more in depth), which include quests, are plentiful enough to keep you from getting bored, but not so deep that they bog down the game too much. Tech researching is also a little more involved and interesting than your standard 4X. Unlike in most 4X games, researching is a little more free-form. Instead of tech trees, there are more like tech levels. To get to the next level (which the game calls Eras), you have to research a certain number of technologies, which can be from any of the main categories (science/production, culture/influence, military, and agriculture/economics). So, if you like, you can choose not to research any low-level (Era I) agriculture/economic technologies and still be able to research Era II agriculture/economic technologies once you've unlocked that level. The anomalies and wide variety of hex benefits (e.g. 1 food, 2 dust, 3 production output if one of your cities extends to that hex) also spice up the game, adding extra elements to consider when making strategic decisions.

The only quibble I have is with the manual battles. While they're enjoyable enough, I've found the system a bit clunky and my units occasionally ignore my orders completely for no apparent reason (not even a terrain reason). Not sure if that's a pathfinding issue or what, but it can make manual battles a little frustrating at times. I've found that you're less likely to lose units in manual battles than the automatic ones (or at least that's what I've seen in my limited experience), so I wish they would take a look at that or somehow make it more clear why units are sometimes like Oh
date: was that an order? You wanted me to do something/go somewhere that might preserve my health or life? How cute. I'm going to go get myself murdered now. kthxbye!" That said
recommended: that's not a huge part of the game and you can absolutely let the computer take care of it if you prefer.\n\nAnyway
hoursPlayed: this is a great game overall and shows that Amplitude Studios is becoming one of those rare Developers You Can Trust To Make Amazing Games That Are Worth Your Money And Will Probably Not F--- You Over With Early Access. (The DYCTTMAGTAWYMAWPNFYOWEA club is an admirable and exclusive one
voteText:
but I think we can all agree that they need a little help with that acronym.)

9.5/10

reviewText:
I would highly recommend this game.  It combines elements of a number of my favorite genres into one of the best-looking packages I've ever seen.  I especially recommend it to all my friends who love the Civilization series.

The entire game is gorgeous.  It may not be the most technically advanced game when it comes to graphics (though it makes great use of depth-of-field, and zooming in/out and discovering new areas are impressively smooth), but the visual design is top-notch, and not just with the art for character and environmental designs.  Hands-down, the UI design is the best I've ever seen in anything, period.  The menus look gorgeous and are easy to understand.  Complicated concepts like resources are abstracted and displayed in a way that really pops.  Even when I didn't understand the game, it was fairly easy to learn by doing, thanks to the great interface design.  Whoever did the visual design for Endless Legends should get a medal.  A really pretty medal.

As for gameplay, it's a 4x at its core, with a lot of similarities to Civilization 5.  However, it boils down a lot of the more obtuse and complicated aspects of the genre into something a little more manageable.  A smaller number of meaningful and balanced choices and tradeoffs is the name of the game here, and it makes for riveting gameplay.  The one more turn" aspect of the genre is in full force here.  Every session so far ends when I finally look at the clock and realize it's 4 in the morning when I thought it was 1 at the latest.

It also adds a nice twist by having an actual battle system.  When two armies meet
date: their battle isn't decided just by stats.  Instead
recommended: you play a tactical turn-based game in the vein of X-Com and Final Fantasy Tactics
hoursPlayed: where unit positioning and targeting are just as important as the gear and levels you bring to the fight.\n\nEndless Legend also borrows some of the best elements of RPGs.  There are unique hero units you can customize with gear and skill trees as they level
voteText: and you can customize every single unit with gear as well.  This allows you to simply upgrade your base units as your technology progresses
helpfulPercent: or create totally different variations for different purposes.\n\nThe game also has a storyline for each of the 8 (or so?) factions you can play as
votesHelpful: and it allows you to create custom factions.  Completing the story's questline leads to a victory condition while fleshing out the world and offering a few twists on the way.\n\nMan
votesTotal: this game is really good.  And really
votesFunny: really pretty.  Buy it!"

reviewText:
This is a great 4x game concept if still a bit rough around the edges.

The good:
* The map is divided into regions, with no more than 1 city/region, with that city having access to all resources in the region--this eliminates city spam.
* Units are grouped into armies, but armies have a max number of units based on current technology--prevents stacks of doom.
* Cities exploit tiles around them by building districts that must be next to the city center or another district--the city gradually works more and more tiles in it's region under player control.
* Armies have something to do even when not at war, exploring ruins, fighting with other factions in neutral regions, and conducting quests.
* Battles are resolved with a decent--but skippable--tactical combat system.
* Tech is non-linear and varied.
* Units are customizable, with new base patterns acquired by assimulating minor factions.
* A number of different paths to victory--military, science, and quest.
* Different factions have huge differences that making playing them basically a completely different game.

The bad:
* Still some significant bugs, including ones that make it impossible to finish a game even from saves.
* No real documentation or tutorial for a lot of the good new concepts--you just have to figure out a lot of things by trial and error.  Though this can also be fun--Oh
date: *that's* how that works...."\n* The notification system--that a city is not producing anything
recommended: or that you aren't researching any tech
hoursPlayed: is easy to miss
voteText: leading to turns of no production and no research unless you remember to check it every turn.\n* The AI is pretty weak
helpfulPercent: and probably always will be
votesHelpful:
due to the complexity of the options available.
* The UI can be frustrating and confusing.

If you're willing to learn by trial and error as you go
votesTotal: and have a high tolerance for bugs
votesFunny: there are some really good new concepts here.  If not
commentsCount: you might wait a couple of months until some good beginner's guides are written and the game is more stable.\n\nIf you do play it now--notifications appear as icons on the right side of the screen.  Make sure you click on every one every turn--they disappear as soon as you hit End Turn.  And the circle around End Turn has an arrow circle icon next to it--click on that every turn to move your armies
column16: or they'll just sit where they are doing nothing.  And use the scroll wheel on your mouse to zoom out far enough that you get the strategic map--that shows you region bondaries

reviewText:
I have endless space and although I liked it I didn't really give enough time to fully enjoy it. Lots of people say this is endless space in a fantasy setting. I disagree. Although some of the mechanics are similar this game is different. Its also different and a lot more fun than many other fantasy based 4X titles.

So far I am into my first game and practically did not stop for 14 hours. Yes this game does an excellent job of keeping you in it. The game has a brief tutorial which does a great job of familiarising you with the basics. At first the game does appear a bit daunting with so many options and things to remember. After a couple of hours I became comfortable and then everything just seem to get better as my Empire slowly came to life. Breaking my 4x tradition I decided to start with a faction thats focus is on economy. I have to say  its really been good. It makes a change to buy your way to success instead of relying on churning out a constant army. With this faction I buy my army and its ready in an instant. The game consists of several varied and interesting major factions and then you have numerous minor factions.  Whichever major faction you choose they will have their own unique background story and quests.

Units vary but are basically broken down into heroes, support, infantry, cavalry, ranged and flying. You can even make your own units. To conquer regions you need cities and growing your city is a long process. In fact as your research grows you will enter several different ages unlocking even more ablities for the city. As well as battles this game is very much about resource management. I love the way every single hex in the game produces some kind of resource in different quantities. This makes it especially important when deciding where to place your city.

This game is pretty much all about time and planning. I really like it that at the beginning of the game you will be in whats known as a 'cold war' with all the other factions. At this stage there can be no peace treaties and you are quite exposed if you end up next door to an aggressive neighbour. Diplomacy in endless legends takes a long time to bear fruit. One thing I do like about the AI on easier settings is that it doesn't tend to attack you the moment it stumbles across you. I've played too many 4X's in the past where you literally get jumped on by the AI before you have started. The great thing about endless is that you start off with a limited number of diplomatic options. The others only come later if you research them. All the other AI factions in the game behave in a specific way. Some are expansionists while others are pacifists. This becomes apparent over time when you see how the factions behave towards each other and the size of their territory.

On to the map. Its one of the best and most intuitive I've seen in a 4x. Randomly generated hex landscapes with varied environments from cold wastes to desert. Each will effect how units interact with it. Scattered across the landscape are numerous weird anomalies, exploitable resources, explorable ruins and minor factions. At any point you can smoothly zoom right in and out of the map to get an overview of the empires. The map is big and takes a long time to fully explore. Minor factions play a role in that you need to pacify them early or they will become a threat with their wandering armies. You can even assimilate a limited number of pacified factions which will give you access to one of their units.

Battles are fought on a zoomed in version of the region it takes place on. Then its a simple turned based hex battle which goes through a number of phases before the outcome is decided. The environment your units are in at the time will have an effect. Some may think the battles are too simplified with limited options and no spell books like with HoMM games. To be honest I think it works just fine for endless. After a battle if you win your units will earn experience points and gradually level up. This makes keeping veteran armies alive essential for the later game.

The music score is superb and blends into the game perfectly.

There is a lot more to this game than what I have touched on in this review. Be sure that once its got your attention you will be sinking endless hours into it.

10/10

reviewText:
Quite honestly I was on the fence on whether or not to make the purchase on this game.  The screenshots and overall favorable reviews is what sold it to me.  I'm a huge fan of the 4x strategy games and with that being said, I was NOT disappionted in the slightest way with Endless Legend.

Some of the pros with this game include the graphics.  Great graphics, especially when compared to games like Civ and Fallen Enchantress.  The units and factions are also completely fresh.   There are your typical archers and melee units which are both essential to any 4x game but take my word for it, a lot of units are at least slightly different and most are really cool (Especially on your first few play throughs when you first encounter them).  Another pro for me is the added involvement regarding the city building aspect of the game.  Each time your city gains population you gain a Worker" that you can place in specific parts of the building/production within your cities.  If you need buildings or units produced more quickly put more of your "Workers" in the production.  Technologies not getting researched fast enough place them into the science slot etc.

With this being said
date: the game isn't without it's downfalls (In my opinion).  I prefer to have more control over my units during combat.  I would rather control each unit for each move.  This isn't the case in Endless Legend.  When your units are involved in a a battle you basically follow the certain steps.  First off
recommended: the battle map is basically a zoomed in portion of the current location of the map that unit is currently on (This for me is actually a plus and definitely a welcomed change).  However
hoursPlayed: the battle sequence leaves a bit to be desired.  To start you basically have to place your units.  Then you select what you want them to do whether it be to attack a specific unit or if you have a healing unit etc. you decide who you want them heal etc.  The battle then ensues until the next turn where you have the option to change your strategies and the battle sequence proceeds as previously mentioned.  Some may prefer this method as it is simplified but I prefer battle sequences like Age of Wonders 3.\n\nThe modifications also leave a little to be desired for me as well.  Personally I love that fact in Fallen Enchantress where you can outfit your heroes with anything and it shows on the character
voteText: not only on the character screen but when you see them in the world too.  With Endless Legends this portion is true in regards to the weapon and Shield only.  Any new armor etc can be equipped but you will not see them.\n\nOverall I do recommend the game and it has kept me busy for about 16hrs since purchase and I'll be busy for many more hours because of the differences it offers to the genre.  It is fun and when I want a slight change in units/factions/city buidling I'll be starting this one up!"

reviewText: I've sunk many hours into this game ever since I had to take a few days off after getting sick. I've played through several full games as the different factions and found that each of them is very unique. I'd say that this is the biggest thing that the game has over Civilization V. If you're at all interested I recommend you read up on each of these because it would take too long to explain here. The other two big differences are a quest and combat systems. Unlike Civ5's city state quests, they don't involve racing other factions or killing another city state(there are none). They're a bit more interesting and present some semblance of a story for each of the factions. Of course, there's not much depth to be expected of quests in a 4X game, but they do make the game a bit more interesting. The combat system, on the other hand, isn't very good and is kind of tedious, especially because of the slow animations. So I wouldn't recommend picking this game up just becasuse you like turn-based combat. But still, it's there and does add SOME depth to combat which would otherwise just be RNG-based.\n\nI recommend this game, but I'm also not sure if it feels done yet. I've been playing on the 'Hard' difficulty and I've found that diplomacy and other AI behaviors are a bit irrational. I hope this is something that will be addressed in a future patch. I expect it to be.

reviewText:
Endless Legend is very much in the vein of civilisation but with a fantasy setting.
It has more depth than many games of its ilk with a wide range of troops, minor factions and resources.
Unlike many modern games the factions are very different with unique play mechanics that making using a different faction a very different experience.
Recommended for fans of fantasy strategy games.



Added after 23 hours play:

Having played this for longer there are game crashing bugs and occasional errors. Autosaves happen every turn to rescue you from this. If you get errors without a crash then it is best to exit the game as re-opening the game can fix the errors. Hopefully these issues will be fixed in a future patch but be warned if you see an error the game may crash in a future turn but your save is probably fine if you restart.

Some of the features I like from this game:

Seasons mean winter suddenly drops your food and other production, poorly designed empires can find them selves starved. Troops move slowly in winter and it gives a sensible pause in war efforts. Once you have troops with winter resistence via high level skills you can gain advantages in the winter.

Diplomacy has a default state of cold war, one step from peace or war. Peace and Alliances must be researched before being offered and military players can not only ignore diplomacy but also ignore chunks of the research options.

Troops can be edited to give them the latest equipment, then troops built on those original builds can be retrofitted to the current build.

Heroes stationed in cities earn experience as quickly or faster than combat Heroes. The earn experience for everything built at the city so defensive and peaceful empires can still build powerful heroes. Heroes also have a whole chain of skills focused on city boosting.

Each faction has a recommended victory type to aim for.
Cultists for example can only build one city and expand through village conversion instead. Each village gives them resouces, an extra city worker and troops are generated for free in the village. The city can grow a level higher than any other faction and numbers of workers in the end game can be very high due to all the villages converted.
To play each faction to the full you need to embrace there game mechanic and just playing each faction gives a lot of replay.

Difficulty is simpler than other games in the ilk as long as you follow the correct playstyle for your faction and utilise your heroes fully. Anything below normal should be treated as training and normal may be to easy if you play a lot of strategy games.

My first playthroughs with the Wind Walkers took 15+ hours and my second play with Cultists taking less than 8 hours.
If you ignore the story line quests and focus on a quick win on maps other than huge you could do this in a much shorter time.
Playing the remaining factions I expect to spend another 30-60 hours trying out the other 6 main factions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We finally got the release version and it is everything I hoped it would be. I waited for the tutorial to be finished before getting into it, and I'm glad I did because 'Legend' is way different than the other 'Endless' titles in terms of how it's played.

There are still some minor bugs, and technically this is a beta version, but for all intents and purposes the game is complete. The only feature we're missing now is Workshop modding, but honestly this game is so good as-is that mods wouldn't add much at the moment.

I highly recommend this to any 4X gamer, whether you like Civ or not.

[edited to reflect release version]

reviewText:
One of, if not, THE BEST 4X games ever created. So addictive.

Pros:
-Wonderfully diverse factions each with their own unique style of gameplay.
-Amazing UI and detailed maps
-Top notch music
-Easy to learn but with plenty of nuances to master
-Map generator has never dissapointed me
-Combat system is much more in-depth compared to Civ. You can beat the odds by careful planning and using your head in most situations

Cons:
-AI could use some work, normal difficulty feels very easy
-Combat can drag out turns in the later game when you have multiple armies on different battlefronts (luckily theres an auto comabt option for those times when you are confident)
-End-game could use a little more variety. All of your units are researched by mid game.


In the end, all the good parts of this game definitely outshine the bad parts. I'm sure we'll see more content released in the future to further cement this games place in the 4X history books.

10/10

reviewText:
As  a long time Civ player, i was looking for a new 4X to scratch my itch after the somewhat lackluster Civ: Beyond Earth. Endless Legend is a whole other beast from Civ. So while they are botrh 4X, do not buy thinking it'll just be a fantasy Civ game.

That being said, it is an extremely satisfying game, with a complexity that i feel is much deeper than most recent Civ games. From the variety in the factions playstyle, to the absolutely beautiful graphics, the game hits on most points in a unique style not seen in any 4X games.

It does have it's flaws such as the heroes who seem similar across the board, to the lackluster AI. The AI is forgiveable due to most 4X games lacking a challenging AI. The Heroes will be addressed at some point as well i'm sure as the devs, seem to always be tinkering with little bits here and there.

Overall a very enjoyable experience, and IMO the 4X release of the year. If 4X is your type of game, Endless Legend is worth your time to get to know. Learning curve is steep but worth it.

reviewText:
Let me explain why I bought this game : I was hoping to do multiplayer matches with friends for Civilization V. As it turns out, CivV grows slow the longer you play, and online connection with friends fails over and over again. That's why I started looking for an alternative.

With Endless Legend I've had none of those problems so far. Excellent for multiplayer, never lost any connection, very neat UI, and no slowdown symtoms thus far (and I've put 18+ hours into it already). So far so good.

Gameplay itself : the game does play much like CivV (that was a good thing for me, as I was simply looking for something better). It's refreshing to have diverse factions though, some play very differently from others. Supports different kinds of endings, so not just military ones, and I find the trading & diplomacy a lot more natural. Plays a bit faster too, for example, you can send units through tiles twice as fast. The tutorial sadly enough does not cover everything there is to know (so check out city planning online!) but everything is there. Combat is improved compared to CivV : there's either auto-battle (instant fights) or small Age-of-Wonders like sessions. The wonderful thing about it is that these fights occur on the world map itself : if you can reach through the fog of war you can actually see your neighboor doing these little battles, but all battles are executed asynchronously so there's no rapid switching from one to another (which occurs in civV if you enable animated fights during multiplayer). Combat animations are good enough, nothing too fancy, nothing too short.

Soundtrack is ok, you get the mp3 files with the game, which is very nice. The graphics are very nice (although I did read somewhere they are out-dated, they are not, in 'fantastic' settings they are very beautiful). Which brings me to the conclusion this game is great, I find it better than CivV or CivBE (which did not improve CivV that much alas) so definately recommended!

reviewText: This game is everything i've every wanted out of a 4x. I've tried to get into 4x strategy games before, like civ 4, or galactic civilization 2. They play completely different from each other, instead of different flavors of the same meal. I won't go into detail about how the factions are different from each other, because there are some many other game review sites that do it better than i can.\nJust buy the game. You'll enjoy the time you spend with it, i promise.

reviewText:
This game is a 4x strategy fantasy game with hexes, similar to Civ 5, if you will.  The best features of this game are faction diverseness, the beautiful graphics, and the flavor (lots of text descriptions of various resources, unusual anomalies on tiles, etc) as well as the gameplay effects of seasons.  No two factions play the same and each faction has such radically different traits that gameplay is quite different.  For example, one faction lives entirely around Dust (money) and can only heal units, build buildings with money.  This faction does not need food.  Another faction only has one city and their goal is bring about the apocalypse.  They can rapidly build a military by converting lesser factions to their religion.  Graphics are great, reminiscent of the intro scene from HBO's Game of Thrones.  Unlike Civ 5, there are elevations in tiles which gives the game a boardgame-like look.  All in all, very pretty.  Lots of flavor in the game, every faction also has quest storylines that are all different in gently prodding you to expand your empire. These range from building a new city to aiding a lesser faction who will then pay tribute to your empire, etc.  There are also lots of other little interesting quests given to your Hero units that can undertake these quests to help your empire.

Gameplay mechanics are similar to other 4x games like Civ 5 or Warlock: Master of the Arcane.  You can do research, construct buildings, train soldiers, recruit heroes (who can fight in the field or govern your cities), etc.  The most unique mechanics are winter, which greatly reduces all tile yields and unit movement and generally make your life hell.  Think of it as ASOIAF's winter/summer cycles.  Summer is bounty and bliss, winter is hell and can last quite a while.  Another unique feature is that the map (which you can set as in Civ 5: continents, etc.) is divided into regions.  Once a city is placed, that region is locked into that faction until the city is destroyed.  So you're fighting over regions, though some factions have exceptions.  Within regions are little lesser factions, they can be destroyed (but you have to rebuild their stuff), given cash, or have a quest done for them to be pacified.  Once pacified, they can be assimilated into your empire and you can train their units.  These leser factions are important because they are uniqe and provide unit plans so you can build their units.  Your base units suck and you only have three: infantry, support, calvary.  The lesser factions can provide you with flying beasts, centaur creatures, etc.  So these lesser factions are important for your army.  Another interesting mechanic is that you can kit your units out with random stuff you find or build like a Sword of Badassness or a necklace of bravery, etc.  This adds a RPG style for your heroes, who can level up and be more effective.

For the bad stuff, the AI is not clever.  Not at all.  You're going to have to pump up the difficulty to mitigate the stupidity of the AI.  Combat is pretty atrocious and mediocre.  I guess it's realistic because a leader won't be able to give spot to spot commands to generals but I recommend autoresolve because you can't control anything besides the most general 'shoot the guy over here.'  You pretty much just end up watching little figurines walk up to each other and fight without much input from you.  For the laidback, I guess this is fine, but for the OCD micromanagers like me, it's not that fun, especially since the Battle AI can screw you over by moving your units poorly (a la Hearts of Iron 3 AI Takeover).

All in all, if you're buying this game, you most certainly are not buying it for combat.  To say again,  the best part of this game is the uniqueness of the factions and for that alone, having to use different playstyles (you can also make custom factions) to succeed makes it worth it if you have money to spend.  My opinion, wait a bit to buy it on sale but there's no harm in buying it full priced.

reviewText:
Wow, what a game. Honestly, it's hard to actually dislike a game like this, to me at least, or in general, an expierienced strategy game player. If we speak about the game, the simplest thing is, it's a combination of the tile system of Civilization Five, and the story, unit systems, and advancements of Endless Space.

If we get complicated...
Endless Legend is to Endless Space, as Warhammer is to Warhammer 40 Thousand. Except Endless is actually relative to all the games. They all connect in some way, and they are similar. All Endless games are heavy on Strategy, and are difficult games in general, to most. If you liked Endless Space, or Dungeon of Endless, there is a fair chance that you will like, possibly love, Endless Legend.
The Good is -
Lovely UI, look wise
Specific Graphics, sharp edges except for units and some factions
Well science trees and techs, if some are illogical
An EXP system for next to every unit, I think, anyway.

Nuetral
Everything is explained by the magical essense called Dust.
Smart AI
Enough variety that a single strategy may not work every time.

Bad
Quests, sometimes they require you to achieve or do something, that is not actually possible for a very long time. IE, a quest recieved on turn 5 may not be fulfilled until turn 50.
Lore breaking, I suppose? Lore tech- Vaulters survive, and are a faction in Endless Space, which takes place in 3000, EL takes place very early.
Random surroundings. A dirt field having a random tile of sand, or a desert, sand or ice, having water.

reviewText:
I would highly recommend this game.  It combines elements of a number of my favorite genres into one of the best-looking packages I've ever seen.  I especially recommend it to all my friends who love the Civilization series.

The entire game is gorgeous.  It may not be the most technically advanced game when it comes to graphics (though it makes great use of depth-of-field, and zooming in/out and discovering new areas are impressively smooth), but the visual design is top-notch, and not just with the art for character and environmental designs.  Hands-down, the UI design is the best I've ever seen in anything, period.  The menus look gorgeous and are easy to understand.  Complicated concepts like resources are abstracted and displayed in a way that really pops.  Even when I didn't understand the game, it was fairly easy to learn by doing, thanks to the great interface design.  Whoever did the visual design for Endless Legends should get a medal.  A really pretty medal.

As for gameplay, it's a 4x at its core, with a lot of similarities to Civilization 5.  However, it boils down a lot of the more obtuse and complicated aspects of the genre into something a little more manageable.  A smaller number of meaningful and balanced choices and tradeoffs is the name of the game here, and it makes for riveting gameplay.  The one more turn" aspect of the genre is in full force here.  Every session so far ends when I finally look at the clock and realize it's 4 in the morning when I thought it was 1 at the latest.

It also adds a nice twist by having an actual battle system.  When two armies meet
date: their battle isn't decided just by stats.  Instead
recommended: you play a tactical turn-based game in the vein of X-Com and Final Fantasy Tactics
hoursPlayed: where unit positioning and targeting are just as important as the gear and levels you bring to the fight.\n\nEndless Legend also borrows some of the best elements of RPGs.  There are unique hero units you can customize with gear and skill trees as they level
voteText: and you can customize every single unit with gear as well.  This allows you to simply upgrade your base units as your technology progresses
helpfulPercent: or create totally different variations for different purposes.\n\nThe game also has a storyline for each of the 8 (or so?) factions you can play as
votesHelpful: and it allows you to create custom factions.  Completing the story's questline leads to a victory condition while fleshing out the world and offering a few twists on the way.\n\nMan
votesTotal: this game is really good.  And really
votesFunny: really pretty.  Buy it!"

reviewText:
This is a great 4x game concept if still a bit rough around the edges.

The good:
* The map is divided into regions, with no more than 1 city/region, with that city having access to all resources in the region--this eliminates city spam.
* Units are grouped into armies, but armies have a max number of units based on current technology--prevents stacks of doom.
* Cities exploit tiles around them by building districts that must be next to the city center or another district--the city gradually works more and more tiles in it's region under player control.
* Armies have something to do even when not at war, exploring ruins, fighting with other factions in neutral regions, and conducting quests.
* Battles are resolved with a decent--but skippable--tactical combat system.
* Tech is non-linear and varied.
* Units are customizable, with new base patterns acquired by assimulating minor factions.
* A number of different paths to victory--military, science, and quest.
* Different factions have huge differences that making playing them basically a completely different game.

The bad:
* Still some significant bugs, including ones that make it impossible to finish a game even from saves.
* No real documentation or tutorial for a lot of the good new concepts--you just have to figure out a lot of things by trial and error.  Though this can also be fun--Oh
date: *that's* how that works...."\n* The notification system--that a city is not producing anything
recommended: or that you aren't researching any tech
hoursPlayed: is easy to miss
voteText: leading to turns of no production and no research unless you remember to check it every turn.\n* The AI is pretty weak
helpfulPercent: and probably always will be
votesHelpful:
due to the complexity of the options available.
* The UI can be frustrating and confusing.

If you're willing to learn by trial and error as you go
votesTotal: and have a high tolerance for bugs
votesFunny: there are some really good new concepts here.  If not
commentsCount: you might wait a couple of months until some good beginner's guides are written and the game is more stable.\n\nIf you do play it now--notifications appear as icons on the right side of the screen.  Make sure you click on every one every turn--they disappear as soon as you hit End Turn.  And the circle around End Turn has an arrow circle icon next to it--click on that every turn to move your armies
column16: or they'll just sit where they are doing nothing.  And use the scroll wheel on your mouse to zoom out far enough that you get the strategic map--that shows you region bondaries
column17: resources
column18: unexplored ruins
column19: etc."

reviewText:
This game is one of the better 4x games that I've ever played. Each faction that I have played has been very different from the ones that came before it, both in aesthetics and gameplay. The world is gorgeous, the art is gorgeous, the diplomacy screens are gorgeous. The game has this unique techno-fantasy feeling going on.

Focus of the game seems to be more on the building than on the heroes, so on the 4x spectrum I would place it closer to civilization than to something like HOMM. The game is a fantasy setting, but there is barely any magic so it also doesn't exactly have the feel of Master of Magic or other fantasy 4x games. Large cities sprawl across the land in a satisfying way, reminding me of what Elemental tried to do but failed at.

Combat is different than other 4x games I've played. It is kind of a tactical/real time hybrid. Each fight is six rounds of issuing orders to your units and then watching the orders resolve. Sometimes the way things play out make slower units unable to carry out their planned orders, so a wrench can be thrown into your movement/attack orders.

I've been playing on standard settings and each game takes about six hours or so. The time just flies away. It's just so damned immersive.

reviewText:
I've played a lot of strategy games over the years and this is one of the better ones. A lot of 4x games (not including space 4x) tend to be heavily modeled after the Civilization series, not Endless Legend though. This game is very much its own game.

Pros:
Each Faction plays very differently from each other. Necrophages can't have peace or alliances, Broken Lords don't need food. Drakken can force peace upon another player, Roving Clans can't declare war etc. Each faction truly is a vastly different playstyle.

The game is beautiful. A minor thing that just makes it more enjoyable.

The battle system is interesting. More in depth than Civ's smack two units against each other, but not as in depth as Age of Wonders 3 where you control each unit on the battle field.

The world is very diverse and there are quests, ruins, minor factions etc. that make exploring both profitable and enjoyable.

Unit Customization. You can alter your units with different armor, weapons and trinkets to suit your needs. You take a basic unit from your faction (or assimilated minor factions) and equip them with different equipment to make them stronger or more specialized. For instance you could have a lance weilding Stalwart that does a lot of damage, or one that can take as much damage as you throw at it.

Heroes: Strong units that lead armies or govern cities. Very useful and very cool.

Mixed:
The region system is somewhat strange. When you settle a region with a city, you own that whole region. However, only the tiles directly around your city are worked. You also can only found a single city per region. This means that many areas that would make excellent cities are wasted. On the other hand all the strategic and luxury resources in the region can be harvested by the single city. You also don't get AI settling right next to your city to steal a resource like in Civ.

Cons:
Limited number of Units. Each faction only has 4 base units. You can assimilate different minor factions for their units but there is a limited number of slots to do this. Compared to other games there aren't many units around. However each faction has three unique units (the settler is common to almost all the factions).

AI can travel into your territory automatically and can attack your units outside of your territory without declaring war. You have to declare peace for them not to be able to attack your units and declare closed borders to keep them out of your territory. Both of which cost influence.

Declaring war costs influence. Severely annoying and pointless. The other diplomatic stuff makes sense. This does not. You don't need to influece someone to declare war, you just attack them.

reviewText:
Genre Fusing Design

Booting up Endless Legend for the first time I knew I was in for something special. I had previously played the 4x Space Civ Simulator, Endless Space, and thoroughly enjoyed it. Both are made by Amplitude Studios and are part of their multiple-game and multiple genre universe spanning series that have been released in rapid succession over the last few years. Endless Space, Endless Legend, and Endless Dungeon, are the three games currently released from Amplitude. All giving their own slightly varied experience.

Endless Legend is the most recent iteration of the endless universe. Starting the game up I was surprised to find a very sparse menu. This is something common between all of the Amplitude games. A minimalistic styled menu that gives you little to do but jump right into their game and get started. That's exactly what I was eager to do.

What the Endless series also excels at is punishing mistakes. The first few times I played I was decimated by nearly every other civilization in the game. Still though, each time I played I made progress. This is one of my favorite parts about civilization builders. Failing and returning to re-build my civilization stronger and more robust. After about 4 times playing through, I finally conquered the world and won. In total this took about 20 hours just to give you an idea of how long it takes to become proficient.

Personally I won by taking the military route after I began falling behind other civilizations in points, however it caused my people endless unhappiness to be ruled by a dictatorial warlord. Still though it was a win even though it wasn't by the conditions I had originally intended. Most of the civilizations have conditions they are better suited to winning with, but every option is always open.

The science ladder" you climb while playing brings you into several era as you play. Each era increases the power available to units and the technology but also increases the production requirements of each city. This adds a depth that includes time as a measurable resource that must be managed. After playing Civilization games I have to say that this is a small change but makes a large difference in how quickly you may want to uncover new technologies.

This combined with the happiness mechanic makes even advancing in production and technology a balancing act. Destroying facilities and units that require upkeep from previous eras can actually help you in the short run to recover and quickly produce more powerful units. Other regular resources are provided in the same way most are in 4x turn based games. They are however more difficult to balance and utilize properly. Running short on resources is common and so is having to make hard decisions.

The biggest draw that I saw in the game was combat
date: and the turn based mechanics. As far as I could tell
recommended: 2 people would take turns at 1 time. Which means you would be moving units at the same time and so there is at least a bit of real-time attention needed as if you are paying little attention to what your units are doing they can be attacked easily. Prioritizing movement over building can save or ruin opportunities. Combat between units is played out simultaneously on your turn between armies in a tiled strategy turn-based format. I know that this type of combat has gotten a lot of flak in reviews as a negative aspect to the game
hoursPlayed: but I consider it a positive.\n\nConsider for a moment that the entire "default" game takes place over 300 turns
voteText:
the combat helps break up the repetition of the turns with something different and stimulating in a different way. Everything Endless Legend does seems fresh even though it utilizes formulas from many previous games. The fusion of turn based civ building and combat works perfectly with the way the game is paced in my opinion.

I for one am eagerly awaiting the further release of games in the endless series. I can't wait to see what Amplitude studios comes up with next.

You'll like this game if: You like fully fleshed out universes with full stories for each faction that include an over-arcing mission to allow for victory. Highlights include great combat
helpfulPercent: wonderfully balanced civ building and well integrated mechanics that don't allow for much exploitation.\n\nFrom my blog at: bigdadgamer.blogspot.com"

reviewText:
At first, Endless Legend looks like Civ 5 put into a fantasy world. While they have several things in common, mostly building an empire through diplomacy, conquest, and expansion, Endless Legend has several features that separates it from Civ 5.

First is how different each of the factions feel and how they are played. In Civ 5, the difference between playing different
factions generally boils down to small percentages. While these can drastically affect the game, you will mostly play the way everyone else does. In Endless Legend, each faction has its own distinctive traits as well as playstyles. One faction can force peace on other factions while another can teleport their units to cities. These differences become even more interesting as you start creating your own factions. In short, if you find yourself playing the Roving Clans after finishing a game with the Necrophages, you probably won't be using the same strategy.

Second is the winter season. Periodically, winter rolls around and generally makes the game harder. Exactly what it does varies from game to game, which can provide a whole new set of challenges with each individual game. It also adds a good bit of difficulty. In Civ 5, the only thing that usually keeps your armies at bay are mountains and other rough terrain. While rough terrain is also in Endless Legend, winter will drastically slow an army down and effectively make combat a fairly rare occurence during winters (at least until the mid to late game as you find ways to become immune to winter's effects). As the winters get longer, the game becomes more difficult, with the actions you take during the summer becoming much more important when the next winter rolls around.

Third is unit customization. In Civ 5, your units become better as you advance through the research tree and they are generally static throughout save for the upgrades they get when they level up. In Endless Legend, your units each have their own equipment set that you can customize to your liking. If you're looking to make your ranged unit zip across the map while hitting hard, you can give them the equipment they need to do that (after you research it, anyway). Unit customization also allows your army to adapt to the situation at hand. If you find that your army is equipped to handle flyers while the enemy sent in melee and ranged units, you can retrofit your army accordingly (provided they weren't killed off before you got the chance).

These are only a handful of the differences between Civ 5 and Endless Legend. Ultimately, if you're looking for a 4X game with some fresh ideas, you'll probably find it in Endless Legend.

reviewText:
I have to say that this is the only 4x strategy game that I have really gotten into, and it is seriously worth it!

Here's the shortened version:

pros:
- different races to play as that actually give a lot of diverse gameplay options
- each race has its own (interesting) quest-line and (vibrant) history
- quests really give you a purpose and a bit of story to drive you forward and keep you engaged with your faction.
- combat system takes the best of Civ V and Total War to create a really fun system!
- seasons!
- relatively simple interface (you probably need to play the tutorial to fully understand it though)
- customise your army units
- very sassy AI!
- beautiful graphics

cons:
- you can't see exactly how strong an enemy is before you attack (at least, i havent found a way yet)
- tutorial is quite heavy, but also worth it so....
- cities are a little hard to see clearly as there is a lot of stuff going on...
- it is a little buggy and often crashes when I play multiplayer, but not enough to deter me from the game!

The long version:

What I like most about this game is the sense of real diversity between each 'culture/races/people'. They each have very specific and drastically different ways of playing them. For example you have a race that is a cult - they can't build extra cities so conquering by force is useless, so instead of soldiers they have preachers who spread their influence and 'take over' other players' settlements through spreading their cult. Another clan is basically vermin zombies who don't even have the option of diplomacy - all they can do is attack other players and eat them or turn their enemies into zombies which they can then control. Or a third one is a bunch of metal armours with souls inside them so they don't require any food resources! There is much more than that but they all have advantages and disadvantages that are really well balanced and truly FEEL different and diverse!

On top of that the combat system is really interesting.

First of all, each race only gets 4 different base units. That's it. But wait for it..... you get to customise them! As you level them up you get access to tier 2, 3 etc items like armour, weapons, and jewelery which all give you different stats which means you can create different units tailored to your own style of play or needs. For example I'm playing with the woodsland people (not their official name) and i have access only to archers at first. But I have created 2 different types of archers through this system - some are better at fighting infantry units whereas my second class is stronger against flying units. And now I also spent a while upgrading all my unit designs so that I can manufacture better units. There aren't THAT many different options, but there are enough to make it diverse and you can have a lot of fun with it. I also just like the ability to upgrade your units instead of simply receiving new units and you don't really know what they do. This way, I really am getting to know my army for once.

Secondly, it's not like in Civ V where your units throw javelins from one hexagon to another hexagon or something like that. In battle you have your little units and they each take up 1 square, so you can control each of them individually, at first you need to decide where to place them (they get advantages or disadvantages based on terrain) and then you decide which enemies they attack. It's the same basic concept as in total war, but with less units and turn-based. You're also able to see the stats of your opponents and so can strategise pretty nicely without it taking forever or being overly complicated.

The only down side is that you can't really tell the strength of an enemy army until you have engaged in battle with it (which has meant that 1 and a half of my armies has been accidentally wiped out because of that. But i think that is mostly because i had only archers. Because i didn't have access to anything else at that point because i was focusing on production instead of armies.)

Finally, quests. I haven't play that many 4x strategy games but I haven't seen quests like these before. And I love them. I tend to play mostly RPGs because I like story and my main concern with 4x games such as Civ V was that I didn't really care about my people. But not in Endless Legend. Oh no. The quests and bits of story you get gives you motivation and a purpose and that is what is keeping me playing this game! And I don't even have time for it! It feels like there is a story happening - you're not just developing your community for nothing, you've got a purpose and i love that!

Basically, it's complex, but simple enough to understand - just the way i like my games.

reviewText:
GOOD:
- Pretty. Sparkly.
- Factions play quite differently from each other.
- Frequently updated, with an expansion coming soon.
- Customizable factions, and lots of world generation options.
- Minor factions (think city states) can give you passive bonuses and unique units.
- Lots of win conditions.
- Reinforces my opinion that winter is the worst season.

MIXED:
- The combat is weird. You assemble military units into armies, which can be moved around as a group, so you don't have to give orders to each of your fifteen thousand units. Then you smash your armies into other armies. You have very little control over actual fighting, which can be annoying, but if one army is much stronger than the other, you can just auto-resolve the fight to save time.

BAD:
- UI is too busy, and the text is too small.
- No mini-map or strategic mode.
- Diplomacy needs major changes, as any agreements you make can be broken immediately. (Market ban rage!!)
- Almost nobody is playing multiplayer.
- There's no way to tell a city to produce nothing (or just gold/science like Civ). It will nag you every turn.
- The AI is mega stupid and unfriendly, even on the easiest difficulty.
- The world is split into pre-defined regions, and you can only have one city per region.
- Quests are too strict. I've had to raze several of my own cities in order to re-do stuff the quest demanded.
- Certain sounds don't behave according to volume settings.
- I have a good computer, and yet a duel between me and an AI lags worse than a six person Civ multiplayer game.
- No steam workshop at the moment.
- Very few characters for city/army names.

This sounds like a lot of complaining, but I actually like the game. It just hurts my eyeballs after a while. It's not better than Civ 5, however. If you've never played this sort of game before, seriously get Civ 5 instead. If you've already played Civ and want something new, this is a decent pick up.

reviewText:
Endless legends is a game unlike any I have played before. It begins much in the way a game of civilizaiton would, you place a capital and branch out to new cities through the use of settlers, conquests, bribes, and even an intriguing quest system. If you enjoy games like civilization revolution then you will love this unique twist and style that endless legends brings to the genre.

While this game is one of the best games of the genre it does have its draw backs. Throughout my play through I began to notice a few irritating things that I feel are necessary to understand about this game before purchase. My first point would be to say that this game is not one that encourages variety. Every faction has three basic units that are unlocked fairly early on, and then they are allowed to assimilate a few minor factions along the way in order to broaden their unit scope. While this may not seem like a big deal to many people it does put certain factions at a major disadvantage against experienced players. My most recent encounter with this is that the Mezari start the game with ranged units that are able to move and shoot all in the same turn, this allows them to kite early game fights and put almost all other factions into the dirt early game. While this may seem like something that many people see as counterable you have to realize that certain factions such as the drakken and the broken lords have no way of countering a ranged unit as they have no late game ranged units of their own without using a valuable assimilation slot.

While this game does have its flaws, it is almost impossible to pass up. Its unique quest system sets it apart from the other titles in this genre, as you now no longer have to build a final building but instead with each faction you are encouraged to follow a specific path that will also allow you win the game. Knowing these paths for each faction you are offered a very interesting way of now denying your allies victory, without having to declare war. We also see the hero system in this game help to further its path to the top of my list of most played games. This game rewards those who use its heroes correctly, offering multiple skill tree paths and roles for heroes. A fully leveled hero in this game could be the difference maker in a battle, as a support hero might be what is needed to keep one militia group alive against multiple titans.

I strongly recommend this game to any lovers of the civilization series, it sticks to the basic city building aspect of the civ series, all the while giving a unique spin on the battle system and diplomacy system.

reviewText:
Endless Legend is a nice take on the 4X genre, and I could summarize it as the child of the Civilization and Age of Wonders series. It's focused on tech research and city building and administration like Civilization but still has the very interesting tactical aspect of combat of AoW; moreover, you still have the possibility to upgrade your current units and heroes with the latest weapons, armor and artifacts you have researched -- a bit like what you can do in Stardock's Fallen Enchantress or in the classic Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.

A novel aspect of EL with respect of all the games I've mentioned is that the game map is divided into regions and each region can host upto one town only; this makes things a bit more interesting as the town has to be placed strategically in accordance with which resources the single region has to offer.

The graphics style is really appealing to me, and the music (that you get also in MP3 format bundled with the game download for free) really nails the mood and tempo of the game.

The only bad thing that I can say about EL is that the AI isn't very challenging at all; sometimes it could just stay idle in its initial territory for the most part of the match -- that's what happened to the Mezari in my first ever game. If this one issue is fixed, EL can become a true classic gem of the genre.

My vote: 8.5/10

PS: I'm still waiting for the Linux release!

reviewText:
Having played Endless Space, I was very excited to see Amplitude release a new 4X game, and I wasn't disappointed. Endless Legend is a beautiful game, with a unique visual style that sets it apart from Civilization V and others. The gameplay is as deep as you want it to be, with little to lots of micromanagement available. It is enjoyable to play once you understand the mechanics, but getting that far can be a little difficult.

The main drawback of the game is that it feel very hard to understand at the start. There is a tutorial, but it doesn't do a great job of showing you anything more than the very basics. It took more than one failed-start of a game before I was able to make any significant progress. It also sucks up your time - but with this genre of game that's to be expected.

Maybe not if you're a newbie to the concept of 4X as it can be a bit information overload for a while, but overall, I would definitely recommend.

reviewText:
It's like fantasy Civ 5, but *better*. I can't stress the 'better' enough.  As a token player of the Civ IP who got Endless Legend on sale just as a game to play with my SO, I was startled to find that I utterly adore Endless Legend and have been playing inordinate amounts of the single player, too.

The factions have very real differences in playstyles and aesthetics, and the customization available to enhance your strengths or make up for your strategic shortcomings are, ha, endless: from the bonuses of assimilated minor factions or the units they grant you, the research paths you choose, the tailoring of armorments for you military units, the skills you train your heroes in, even your cities themselves can be customized to your playstyle.

There's so much more I could tell you...but then again, I could just go play it instead.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This one's a bit of a tough recommendation. If youo're looking for a 4x game with a really intriguing story and a neat take on the 4x formula, this is a great game. Also, be prepared to do a lot of micro managing. If you're into that (as I am) you'll have a lot more fun with it. The story behind each of the 8 playable factions is deep enough to get invested in, but open enough for the player to make their own story out of it.

However, there are some very frustrating things with the quest system. Quests are a very important part of the game, but they are by far the weakest part. There are many quests whose completion requirements are overly specific in what is required, and yet strangely general in how they are told. Many times I thought I completed a quest and hadn't because of some minor detail which wasn't fully recounted. For example, one quest required me to grow a city to the size of 8. The city was already at a size of 14, but the quest didn't complete. I had to starve the city down to 7 population, and then re-grow it to get the completion on the quest. Possibly that was intentional, but it was extremely frustrating. Twice, the game actually bugged in such a way that completing a quest was impossible.

There have also been more than a few crashes, but the game autosaves every turn so it's not that much of a problem, and with luck that will get fixed in a later patch.

Overall, mostly great 4x game that could use a few patches. If the quests are fixed and the crash bugs are removed, this game is very solid.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
As  a long time Civ player, i was looking for a new 4X to scratch my itch after the somewhat lackluster Civ: Beyond Earth. Endless Legend is a whole other beast from Civ. So while they are botrh 4X, do not buy thinking it'll just be a fantasy Civ game.

That being said, it is an extremely satisfying game, with a complexity that i feel is much deeper than most recent Civ games. From the variety in the factions playstyle, to the absolutely beautiful graphics, the game hits on most points in a unique style not seen in any 4X games.

It does have it's flaws such as the heroes who seem similar across the board, to the lackluster AI. The AI is forgiveable due to most 4X games lacking a challenging AI. The Heroes will be addressed at some point as well i'm sure as the devs, seem to always be tinkering with little bits here and there.

Overall a very enjoyable experience, and IMO the 4X release of the year. If 4X is your type of game, Endless Legend is worth your time to get to know. Learning curve is steep but worth it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me explain why I bought this game : I was hoping to do multiplayer matches with friends for Civilization V. As it turns out, CivV grows slow the longer you play, and online connection with friends fails over and over again. That's why I started looking for an alternative.

With Endless Legend I've had none of those problems so far. Excellent for multiplayer, never lost any connection, very neat UI, and no slowdown symtoms thus far (and I've put 18+ hours into it already). So far so good.

Gameplay itself : the game does play much like CivV (that was a good thing for me, as I was simply looking for something better). It's refreshing to have diverse factions though, some play very differently from others. Supports different kinds of endings, so not just military ones, and I find the trading & diplomacy a lot more natural. Plays a bit faster too, for example, you can send units through tiles twice as fast. The tutorial sadly enough does not cover everything there is to know (so check out city planning online!) but everything is there. Combat is improved compared to CivV : there's either auto-battle (instant fights) or small Age-of-Wonders like sessions. The wonderful thing about it is that these fights occur on the world map itself : if you can reach through the fog of war you can actually see your neighboor doing these little battles, but all battles are executed asynchronously so there's no rapid switching from one to another (which occurs in civV if you enable animated fights during multiplayer). Combat animations are good enough, nothing too fancy, nothing too short.

Soundtrack is ok, you get the mp3 files with the game, which is very nice. The graphics are very nice (although I did read somewhere they are out-dated, they are not, in 'fantastic' settings they are very beautiful). Which brings me to the conclusion this game is great, I find it better than CivV or CivBE (which did not improve CivV that much alas) so definately recommended!

reviewText: It's hard to believe that despite having played 55 hours of the game (which is a lot for me, I tend to set games aside at the 25-30 hours mark), I've only tried two of the factions so far. But if you like science-fantasy and Civ-like games, this is a must-play; it sucked me in in a way that Civ 5 didn't. The setting is amazing (I'd love to play this as a tabletop RPG) and most of the factions feel like they have a unique gameplay of their own rather than just having their specialties. My only complaint is the AI opponents who feel a bit week and often make incoherent decisions (Galactic Civilizations II set the bar really high for me; also devs say fine-tuning the AI is high on their priority list for updates), but the game remains deeply engrossing even in single player (and there is a multiplayer mode I haven't tried yet). My opinion is that this is the 4X game to play right now.

reviewText: Fantastic, simply fantastic! My new favorite 4x game. It's like Civ 5 had a baby with the unit design part of Sins of the Solar Empire, then that baby went and got it on with the city building aspect of Galactic Civilizations, then their offspring of awesomeness went and birthed the 4x mesiah with the UI and Anomoly mechanic from Endless Space. That's pretty much it exactly. There is no space travel/colonization of any kind to be clear, but aspects of all those games are very prevalent and if you liked any of them along with Civ you'll  really enjoy this one.

reviewText:
I didn't know that i like 4x games until i played Endless Legend. This game doses 3 things really well.

1. Gameplay and Factions.
There are 8 different factions in this game. Each faction plays different than the others.

that gets a cut off of the market, because it controlls the market (lorewise).

2. Lore and Gameplay
What leads me to my second point. The gameplay is connected to the lore of the game.
The lore itsself is very rich and for fans it is also connected to the other Endless games, like
Endless Space and Dungeon of Endless.

3. Gameplay mechanics
Its interface and game design is simple and complex at the same time.
But it is simple enough to be able to learn the complex stuff as you play the game over and over.
I never got into CiV 5. I just didn't get it. Now that i played Endless Legend
i finally know what these 4x games are all about.

That game got to be my game of the year 2014 period.

reviewText:
Having played Endless Space, I was very excited to see Amplitude release a new 4X game, and I wasn't disappointed. Endless Legend is a beautiful game, with a unique visual style that sets it apart from Civilization V and others. The gameplay is as deep as you want it to be, with little to lots of micromanagement available. It is enjoyable to play once you understand the mechanics, but getting that far can be a little difficult.

The main drawback of the game is that it feel very hard to understand at the start. There is a tutorial, but it doesn't do a great job of showing you anything more than the very basics. It took more than one failed-start of a game before I was able to make any significant progress. It also sucks up your time - but with this genre of game that's to be expected.

Maybe not if you're a newbie to the concept of 4X as it can be a bit information overload for a while, but overall, I would definitely recommend.

reviewText: First Impressions: They've come a long way since Endless Space. reviewText: Don't take me too seriously, I only play bots or friends. I'm also not really a big Civ player because Civ V puts me to sleep for some reason. That said, I find this game a lot more interesting to think about. It has no serious grounding in reality, so the races, units and mechanics are all pretty out-there and imaginative.\n\nI think this is a great strategy game. It has interesting mechanics and highly varied races, and is generally very well-designed and pretty to look at. Great for people who (like me) love thinking up their own strategies -- the game allows you to customise its races (which are each already fairly unique) pre-game, and customise your units in-game, which makes each round turn out quite differently and keeps you brainstorming new options as the game progresses. Generally speaking there are many viable options, some seeming absolutely bonkers at the outset, and it's a lot of fun to tweak races and units to min-max your game plan.

reviewText:
Honestly, this is the fantasy-flavored Civilization/4X game that I've always wanted.

In a nutshell, you're building a civilization on a dying planet on which winters are getting longer and harsher. You have the usual supremacy/extermination/diplomacy victory conditions that you expect, but you also have access to some RPG elements. Each faction has a lore quest that leads to a victory. And along the way, you also have the opportunity to take on other lore based quests, and outfit your heroes and armies as you see fit.

The heroes are another interesting mechanic. Apart from leading your armies (think generals in Civ, or hero units in Warcraft III), they can also be assigned as governors to your cities, with a skill tree specific to governance.

The lore and worldbuilding is, in my opinion, some of the best in the fantasy genre I've seen in quite some time. Each faction is unique beyond their unit designs/builds, and each gives you specific goals to work toward.

THe only caveat - if you're coming from or prefer straight 4X games like Civ or Master of Orion, you may be put off by the focus on questing and lore.

Also - the devs are pretty great, with another upcoming faction expansion. Definitely a buy.

reviewText:
Endless Legend is easier than Endless Space, and by easier, I mean less stressful, a lot less stressful.

With that being said it's also a vast improvement on what Endless Space set up, Endless Legend's UI is lot less cluttered and easier to navigate, stuff (anomalies, terrain) is spread out over the hexes, and luxuries do more than provide industry, science and so on, when you have enough of them you can activate them for a major boost.

There's also a lot less big waiting for units or improvements to finish production, which is really nice when setting up new cities. Not to mention you can equip heroes now, and best of all the combat system is no longer card playing but actual right there battles, turn based.

All in all Endless Legend hits a high mark just like Endless Space did, and was a major relief after dealing with stress Endless Space may put on, and Endless Legend is no less difficult than Endless Space is/was, so expect a challenge, bring your A-game!

reviewText:
This game is great, it has unique civilisations each with unique playstyles, and an immersive story for each faction that ties into the greater story.

Endless legend is a 4X game like Sid miers Civ yet it feels so much better in terms of replay value, when you start out you get a hero, 2 combat units and a settler and once you place down the settler you start the faction questline.

Each city controls a preset region in whihc you need to pacify the minor factions which are shown as villages. The great thing about this is that every time you play you can build a unique army out of these minor factions by assimilating different factions which grants you their units.

There is also the ability to customise your units equiptment which items that grant abilities like chances to stun etc,
Heroes take this ability further with legendary weapons which usually require resources to build but grant a large power boost.


Pros:
+ Interesting factions with their own meaningful story tied into having the player do quests.

+ Ability to make your own custom faction by combining positive and negative traits.

+ Each factions units are way different from each other (stealthy assassins to flying bugs)

+ Minor faction villages provide a lot of extra strategy to the gameplay providing bonuses to your cities and also unique units with their own abilities.

+ DLC pricing is fair and provides a lot of features that change gamplay ( world events, legendary buildings, co-op quests)

+ Co-op quests that show during the game with the guardians expansion

+ soundtrack is awesome as well!

Cons:
-  Some of the quests involve travelling large distances for small rewards
-  Base game deos not have legendary buildings
- Some of the main factions feel constricted in ways they can win (but can be fixed to an extent by custom factions)

reviewText:
This game has an incredible amount of detail. Sid Meier's Civilization is the only thing I can compare it to. The gameplay is relatively similar: turn-based empire building where every construction or unit costs a city's production to create or expand. But where Endless Legend differs is its focus on simplicity. In Civ 5, you see your armies splayed out on the map, each one taking up a space, which makes mass movement a very calculated process. However, Endless Legend allows you to merge your armies to make a larger one and the best part is that army only takes up one space on the map!

One of the highlights for me as an avid RPG player is the focus on customization. You can field heroes much as you can generals in Civ 5. However, instead of Civ 5's seemingly random bestowing of generals, you have much more control in how you obtain your heroes, what they carry into battle, and where they will function in your world. You can customize them using not only their individual ability tree, but also by their race to suit your needs.


Having only played the game for a few weeks, I haven't seen all there is to see in Endess Legend. But I can say it leaves me wanting more every turn I play. Also, the Easy difficulty is much more punishing than you think.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that I will be reviewing the Vanilla version; no expansions included. This game is a great TBS that has its good points far outweight its bad ones. So here ya go:


Pros

- Very interesting factions, they're all really unique and only some are similar to the popular Tolken-kind of races (Wild Walkers as Elves and Vaulters could be somewhat similar to dwarves). Every faction has great lore behind them with a unique questline that can guide you if you need a goal. Also, their armies are completely different from each other. Say you're a Cultist. The two things you lack in your army are infantry and flying units. This is useful because you need to take this into account when fighting different factions as your strengths and weaknesses will be different per race.

- Plenty of victory types. You need to decide which one to go after when you begin the game.

- The customization of units is unique from most other modern TBS games and is something I've only seen since Alpha Centauri.

- It can be viable to go tall or wide, although you may need to take down a few cities along the way.

- Graphics are probably the best I've seen compared to other rival TBS games (Civ:BE). Also, the terrian layout is perfect, I love how there are choak points throughout the map that are made by cliffs and lakes.

- Research is different from what you would usually see in the genre, with no tech trees but instead 'discs.'

- I personally love the tile expansion system with the boroughs and districts. Makes you need to be strategic when expanding.

- Smooth UI. If you learn how to use it, it is very helpful and advanced.


Cons

- Tedious battle system. This is something you'll love or hate, kind of like golf. There is no middle ground really.

- No naval combat, which is a bit of a bummer.

- I've been sitting here trying to think of a third point. Bad AI maybe? Nah, I thought it was pretty cool when the Roving Clans were black mailing me when they took me off the market. Winters are pointless? Well actually they add a lot of depth and require you to time things perfectly when it comes to war. Yeah, I can't think of any other bad points.


The Verdict

Endless Legend Vanilla is a fun and original game, and it's something fans of TBS should try. It puts plenty of great twists on the genre and only suffers from minor details that shouldn't really detract from your enjoyment.

reviewText:
Fantastic game. I am enjoying it much more than either Endless Space (another by the same developer) or any of its competitors I have tried (Age of Wonders 3, Fallen Enchantress). I love the one-city-per-region mechanic. It cuts back on the number of cities while allowing them to grow naturally on the map, but also awards thoughtful placement. Also, the way units are upgraded is a big step up in user friendliness than Fallen Enchantress. Luxury resource mechanics are also an interesting change.

The only gripe I have is the fact that for every battle you have to select 'Auto' again and again if you don't want to go into tactical combat. A feature to remember the last choice, or even a feature to set the default would have been nice.

Overall, great game. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I have Endless Legend Emperor Edition.  I am a big fan of 4x strategy games and had heard good things regarding it.  I greatly liked mods for Civilization where you got to play in a fantasy setting and other 4x strategy games like Fallen Enchantress.

I found things I both liked and that I didn’t about Endless Legends.  First some of the good stuff.  Nice graphics, zoom in and you can check out fine detail.  The customization of units and the heroes was well done and does stay relevant through the game.  The ‘tech’ web that exists was a nice change of pace and I really liked the concept for the emperor planning that happens throughout game.

Now a few things that I didn’t like so much.  First and most important they are doing like Civilization did and what I would consider ‘core’ mechanics of the game are getting released as DLC.  The combat mechanic was also lacking.  While it was nice to see a different combat setup, I don’t think that their attempt was polished enough.  Honestly that is what most of the flaws in the game feel like, polish missing.  No quick save or quick load.  No ability to adjust animation speed for global travel and only able to adjust combat animation speed when starting the game.  A bit of a kick in the teeth was the fact that there was not good endgame movie just a  still saying that you won.

While I do recommend I think you would be better to wait for a Game of the Year edition that has all the DLC and know what you are getting into.  Don’t expect everything perfect, but it is a game that you can enjoy.
